tourName: 2 week Japan family holiday
generalInfo:
This is a private tour for family vacation, no minimium age.

Embark on a perfect tour catered to families and first-time visitors, immersing in Japan's rich history, mountain town aromas, majestic shrines, and palaces.

Explore the country via various Shinkansen bullet train classes, revel in bustling shopping streets, and indulge in Japan's diverse culinary offerings at cozy local eateries and vibrant food markets. Delight in food tastings that offer an authentic local experience, making you feel truly immersed in the culture and flavors.

Places and activities below:
Purify your hands at Meiji Shrine and immerse yourself in Japanese traditions.

Explore Japan's rich heritage by visiting numerous UNESCO World Heritage Sites throughout the country.

Immerse yourself in the vibrant heart of Tokyo's youthful culture.

Witness the breathtaking panoramic view of Tokyo city from the world's tallest free-standing broadcasting tower.

Engage in a fun ramen-making experience for the whole family in Tokyo, unleashing your culinary creativity.

Enjoy a thrilling day at Universal Studios Japan with your children.

Hop on different classes of Shinkansen trains to traverse various regions of Japan.

Speed through the magnificent Japanese Alps and step into traditional folk villages.

Discover the meticulous art of gold-leafing in Kanazawa as you craft your own shimmering masterpiece.

Spend a night in a traditional Japanese ryokan, complete with tatami mat floors and sliding doors.

Absorb the essence of peace at Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park.

dayInfo.description: Tokyo Arrival. Private transfer from airport to hotel. After settling in, enjoy free time to start exploring the city or relax and refresh from your journey. Meals: None

Exploring Tokyo's Heart. Embark on a comprehensive city tour, weaving through Tokyo's past and present: Meiji Jingu Shrine: Immerse in serenity at this spiritual sanctuary. Shibuya: Feel the pulse of modernity and youth culture. Kokyo Gaien National Garden: Stroll under the charming Meganebashi, capturing European flair. Senso-ji Temple: Trace Buddhist history in Asakusa. Tokyo Skytree: Soar for breathtaking cityscapes. Meals: Breakfast

Tokyo's Digital Realm & Gastronomy. Delve into Tokyo's digital frontier and culinary delights: teamLab Borderless: Interact with boundary-pushing digital art. Ramen-Making Workshop: Craft the perfect bowl of noodles. Pokémon Center: Dive into a world of beloved creatures. Anime Café(optional): Savor Tokyo's pop art scene in a themed cafe. Meals: Meals: Breakfast and Lunch

Tokyo to Takayama, via Nagoya. Embark on a journey to Japan's traditional core: Self-Guided Station Transfer: Effortlessly navigate with pre-briefing and tickets. Shinkansen to Nagoya: Speed through landscapes on Japan's iconic bullet train. Private Transfer to Takayama: Arrive in the quaint alpine town. Guided Tour: Uncover Takayama Jinya and Hida Folk Village's rural charm Meals: Breakfast

Takayama to Kanazawa. Continue through Japan's cultural tapestry: Shirakawa-go UNESCO Site: Marvel at the thatched farmhouses. Kanazawa Castle: Step into samurai history. Kenrokuen Garden: Embrace tranquility in a seasonal masterpiece. Meals: Breakfast

Kanazawa to Kyoto. Before departing Kanazawa, savor its cultural gems: Higashi Chaya District: Meander historic teahouse lanes. Gold Leaf Crafting: Add a golden touch to your experience. Thunderbird to Kyoto: Scenic rail journey to the ancient capital. Evening at Leisure: Settle into Kyoto or explore independently. Meals: Breakfast

Kyoto's Cultural Riches. Immerse in Kyoto's timeless beauty: Kinkaku-ji: Glimmering Golden Pavilion. Nijo Castle: Relive feudal grandeur. Arashiyama Bamboo Grove: Stroll beneath towering bamboo. Togetsu-kyo Bridge: Complete your day with scenic Arashiyama vistas. Meals: Breakfast

Kyoto to Osaka, with a Nara Stopover. En route to Osaka, visit Kyoto and Nara's icons: Kiyomizu-dera: Panoramic views from the Pure Water Temple. Fushimi Inari Shrine: Walk through thousands of vermilion gates. Mount Wakakusa: Nara's verdant hilltop vistas. Todaiji Temple( UNESCO): it is the home to numerous national treasures and cultural assets, and so the temple itself was registered as a Historic Monument of Ancient Nara. Meals: Breakfast
Universal Studios Adventure. Entertainment Extravaganza: 1-Day Studio Pass: Dive into movie magic with rides and shows. Guided Transfer Assistance: Hassle-free access to fun. Meals: Breakfast

Onward to Hiroshima. Travel to Hiroshima, steeped in history: Nozomi Train Journey: Swift transit from Osaka. Hiroshima Castle: Echoes of Japan's past. Peace Memorial Park: Reflect on peace amidst poignant memorials. Meals: Breakfast

Discovering Hiroshima and Return. Embrace Hiroshima's serenity and history: Shukkei-en Garden: Miniature landscapes in harmony. Miyajima Island Cruise: Visit Itsukushima Shrine's floating torii. Nozomi Train Back to Osaka: Seamless return with guidance. Meals: Breakfast

Osaka's Cultural Canvas. Experience Osaka's vibrant essence: Kamigata Ukiyoe Museum: Admire traditional prints. Shinsekai Culinary Delights: Savor Osaka's gastronomic treats. Ninja Experience: Unleash your inner warrior. Dotonbori: Evening immersed in Osaka's entertainment hub. Meals: Breakfast
Farewell. Bid adieu to Japan with a private transfer to the airport. Sayonara: Until our paths cross again, safe travels! Meals: Breakfast

tourName: 8 days in Japan holiday
generalInfo: Embark on an unforgettable journey through Japan’s most enchanting cities, from the bustling streets of Tokyo to the serene temples of Kyoto, and the poignant peace of Hiroshima. Discover the rich traditions and modern wonders in this captivating 8-day adventure across Japan’s iconic destinations, blending history, culture, and experiences that promise memories to last a lifetime.

dayInfo.description: Tokyo, Japan: Arrival and First Glimpse of Tokyo Welcome to Tokyo – Shared Airport Transfer Upon arrival, hop on a comfortable shared shuttle for a seamless transfer to your hotel in Tokyo. Relax and take in your first glimpses of this exciting metropolis. Explore Tokyo at Your Own Pace The rest of your day is free for exploration. Wander through buzzing streets, savor local delicacies, or simply unwind after your travels – the city is yours to discover. Overnight in Tokyo Settle into your accommodation and get a good night’s rest, ready for the adventures ahead.

Tokyo - Hakone, Japan: Hakone Escapade: Hot Springs & Scenic Trains Shinkansen Adventure: Tokyo to Hakone Start your day with an exciting bullet train journey from Tokyo to the lush mountain landscapes of Hakone, using your JR Pass for a fast and comfortable ride. Hakone Freepass Exploration Unlock Hakone’s best sights with your 2-day Hakone Freepass E-ticket! Ride cable cars, cruise on Lake Ashi, and visit art museums, shrines, and onsen—all stress-free. Soak and Unwind: Hakone Onsen After a thrilling day of sightseeing, immerse yourself in one of Hakone’s famous hot spring baths, perfect for relaxing those travel-weary muscles. Magical Mountain Evening: Stay Overnight End the day in a cozy Hakone inn, embracing serenity with a delicious local dinner and tranquil mountain views.

Hakone - Kyoto, Japan: Bullet Train to Kyoto & Free Exploration Scenic Bullet Train Journey Depart from Hakone and glide through the Japanese countryside aboard the famed Shinkansen using your Japan Rail Pass. Feel the thrill as you zip toward Kyoto, catching glimpses of Mount Fuji, rice paddies, and charming villages along the way. Arrival and Discover Kyoto on Your Own Arrive in Kyoto and check into your accommodation. The rest of the day is yours! Wander through the historic streets of Gion, get lost among breathtaking temple grounds, or relax in a peaceful garden. Kyoto’s rich culture and elegant atmosphere await your personal exploration. Overnight in Kyoto Settle into your hotel and reflect on your day. Perhaps sample kaiseki cuisine nearby or take a quiet stroll along the Kamogawa River as Kyoto glows softly in the evening light.

Kyoto, Japan: Gion Geisha Secrets & Lantern-lit Wonders Geisha Culture Immersion Meet your guide and journey through the cobbled streets of Gion, marveling at iconic teahouses and learning about the intriguing world of Geiko and Maiko. Listen as your guide reveals the secrets of geisha culture, past and present. Architectural Treasures & Secret Spots Explore beautifully preserved machiya townhouses, exclusive tea houses, and charming boutique shops tucked away from the busy streets. Capture stunning shots of Hõkan Ji Pagoda, a striking emblem of Kyoto’s storied past. Sanctuaries of Serenity Pause at Kennin-ji, Kyoto's oldest Zen temple, soaking in its tranquil gardens (visit approx. 30 mins). Then uncover the allure of Chion-in Temple—a hidden gem adorned with three national treasures and breathtaking, vast grounds. Gion by Twilight As dusk falls, witness the enchanting transformation of Gion, aglow with lantern light—magical lanes for evening strolls and perfect photo opportunities. Insider Recommendations Wrap up your two-hour tour (available at 12 PM, 3 PM, 6 PM, or 8:45 PM) with a tailored list of restaurants, bars, and must-do activities, ensuring you make the most of Kyoto.

Kyoto - Hiroshima, Japan: Bullet Train to Hiroshima & Free Day Speed Across Japan Hop onto the iconic JR bullet train and watch the picturesque landscapes rush by as you journey from Kyoto to the dynamic city of Hiroshima. Freedom to Explore Upon arrival, the day is yours! Stroll through Peace Memorial Park, sample Hiroshima-style okonomiyaki, or lose yourself in vibrant shopping streets and quiet gardens. Settle Into Hiroshima Check into your accommodation and perhaps take a twilight stroll along the Motoyasu River, soaking in the city’s reflective atmosphere before an overnight stay.

Hiroshima, Japan: Cycling Hiroshima: Revival, Heritage, and Hope Meet Up and Kick Off 11:00 or 15:00 Meet your friendly local guide and gear up for your e-bike adventure through Hiroshima—an immersive journey loaded with history and hope. Peace Memorial Park Experience 11:05 or 15:05 Begin by uncovering the profound stories behind the monuments and the iconic Atomic Bomb Dome. Feel the gravity of history as your guide paints a vivid picture of what happened over 70 years ago. A-Bombed Streetcars & Suburban Heritage Sites 12:00 or 16:00 Venture beyond the usual paths, discovering heritage sites and the legendary A-bombed streetcars—survivors of Hiroshima’s darkest day. As you cycle through tree-lined avenues, witness how the city has flourished again, guided by locals who bring firsthand tales and hidden gems to life. Cycle Through a Living Miracle Throughout your ride, absorb Hiroshima’s vibrant rebirth and green surroundings—a testament to resilience. The e-bike journey makes each historical stop engaging and accessible. Finish at Meeting Point 13:00 or 17:00 Wrap up your powerful tour where you started, carrying new perspectives and unforgettable memories of Hiroshima’s indomitable spirit.

Hiroshima - Osaka, Japan: Journey to Osaka & Urban Freedom JR Adventure from Hiroshima to Osaka Set off on a speedy bullet train journey as you leave Hiroshima behind, gliding towards the vibrant metropolis of Osaka. Lean back and enjoy scenic landscapes flashing past your window. Free to Explore Osaka Arrive in bustling Osaka, a city bursting with energy and culinary delights. The afternoon is yours—perhaps dive into the neon-lit streets of Dotonbori, sample local street food, or stroll through peaceful parks and buzzing shopping arcades. Osaka Nightlife & Restful Stay Spend your evening however you wish—enjoy a traditional izakaya dinner or marvel at the dazzling city views from Umeda Sky Building. Retreat to your comfortable hotel for an overnight stay in Osaka.

Osaka, Japan: Fond Farewell & Departure Journey Final Journey to Osaka Airport Wake up and enjoy one last stroll or breakfast in Japan’s vibrant cityscape, savoring every moment before departure. Smooth JR Pass Train Ride Board your train, making the most of your JR Pass one final time. Watch Japan’s scenery whirl by as you head to Osaka Airport in comfort. Farewell to Japan Arrive at Osaka Airport, reflecting on your remarkable adventures. Take time to browse last-minute souvenirs or enjoy a traditional snack before your flight. End of the Journey With unforgettable memories in your heart and souvenirs in your bag, embark on your flight home, marking the end of your incredible Japanese adventure.

tourName: Best of Japan tour
generalInfo:
Travel amongst the streets of Tokyo to the timeless serenity of Osaka. Witness the striking contrasts of tradition and innovation as you ride sleek bullet trains through stunning countryside, gaze at Mt. Fuji from peaceful Kawaguchiko, and explore the soulful streets of Kyoto by lantern light. Reflect in the sacred atmosphere of Koya-san’s mountaintop temples, and dive into the powerful stories of Hiroshima and the beauty of Miyajima. Whether you’re into ancient culture, natural beauty or incredible cuisine, this immersive 10-day experience captures Japan’s rich and varied spirit.

Go beyond the guidebooks with a thoughtfully curated journey that blends Japan’s iconic highlights with meaningful local experiences and cultural depth.

Unwind in handpicked stays, from modern comforts to traditional ryokans with soothing onsens and serene spa settings.

Soak up the charm of Kyoto and Osaka with extended stays that allow time to dive deeper into their historic streets, vibrant neighbourhoods and timeless rituals.

Why You'll Love This Tour :
Go beyond the guidebooks with a thoughtfully curated journey that blends Japan’s iconic highlights with meaningful local experiences and cultural depth.

Unwind in handpicked stays, from modern comforts to traditional ryokans with soothing onsens and serene spa settings.

Soak up the charm of Kyoto and Osaka with extended stays that allow time to delve deeper into their historic streets, vibrant neighbourhoods and timeless rituals.

Sail to the tranquil shores of Miyajima Island, where sacred shrines, floating torii gates and sweeping sea views create an unforgettable atmosphere.

Trace Japan’s complex past and resilient spirit with guided visits through Hiroshima, before heading into the peaceful embrace of Mt. Fuji’s lakeside region.

Discover the spiritual heart of Japan with a visit to Koya-san, home to mountaintop temples, quiet forest paths and centuries of sacred tradition.

dayInfo.description: Kon’nichiwa and welcome to the capital of Japan – Tokyo! Meet your group and tour leader for an informal welcome meeting in the hotel lobby at 6.30pm. With a population of above 10 million people, Tokyo offers endless choices when it comes to shopping, green spaces, entertainment, historical sites, culture, and dining! Accommodation Metropolitan Ikebukuro or similar – 4 Star Included Activities Group Welcome Meeting

Tokyo Rise and shine in the city of Tokyo! After a full breakfast, follow your tour leader to learn about the diverse history and colourful culture of Japan as we visit the Sensoji Temple, Hama Rikyu Garden and Meiji Jingu (Shrine), before making the famous Shibuya/Harajuku walk in the city. Enjoy free time in the afternoon to shape your adventure to your likes. Your tour leader will be happy to recommend the best places and activities to your taste. You can catch some fresh air at the public Ueno Park and visit the Tokyo National Museum within. Or explore one of the many fascinating museums across the city including Edo-Tokyo Museum, Hokusai Museum, or Odaiba Team Labo – home to immersive, futuristic art installations. Accommodation Metropolitan Ikebukuro or similar – 4 Star Meals Breakfast Inluded Activities Hama Rikyu Garden Sightseeing Meiji Jingu Sightseeing Shibuya & Harajuku Walk Entrance Fees Hama Rikyu Garden – 300 JPY

Tokyo, Kawaguchik : This morning your luggage will get forwarded to Kyoto. We will farewell Tokyo for the breath-taking Kawaguchiko. Grab a seat for the train & bus journey as we head towards the scenic lakeside town known for its views of Mount Fuji. Enjoy a peaceful boat ride and (weather permitting) and take the Mt. Fuji Panoramic Ropeway for a bird’s eye view. Accommodation : Route Inn Kawaguchiko – 3 Star Meals : Breakfast, Dinner Included Activities : Boat ride , Mt. Fuji Panoramic Ropeway

Kawaguchik, Kyoto : Kick-start the day with a scenic mountain train & bus ride as we head to Kyoto via Odawara. Considered the cultural and historic heart of the country, Kyoto is brimming with temples, shrines, peaceful gardens, geisha, restaurants, and shops. This traditional city is the perfect place to get lost in! After arrival you will have a walking tour in the Old Town, including Ninenzaka, Sannenzaka and the famous Gion District. Accommodation : Onyado Nono Shichijo Hotel – 3 Star Meals Included : Breakfast Included Activities : Kyoto Old Town Walking Tour

Kyoto : Enjoy a full day to explore the cultural hub of Japan as we roam the city! Immerse yourself in the city’s spiritual side as we visit the famed Fushimi Inari Shrine, stroll through the Arashiyama Bamboo Grove and explore Tenryu-ji Temple. We will finish our tour at the buzzing Nishiki Market and then in the afternoon you will have free time to discover the city. Accommodation :Onyado Nono Shichijo Hotel – 3 Star Meals Included : Breakfast Included Activities : Fushimi Inari Shrine Bamboo Grove Tenryu-ji Temple Nishiki Market

Hiroshima : this morning your luggage will get transferred to Osaka ** Travel by express train to Hiroshima. Hiroshima is well known for the 1945 atomic bomb attack which destructed the entire city within a 2km radius. After the war, great efforts were taken to rebuild Hiroshima. The city was tastefully reconstructed in a way that still pays tribute to the suffering, with a large park built in the city centre – Peace Memorial Park. Following your guide through the park, you will visit the Peace Memorial Museum to learn of the historical war events that took place here. This evening, you can explore Hiroshima on your own. Accommodation : Sotetsu Fresa Inn – 4 Star Meals Included : Breakfast Included Activities : Peace Museum visit Peace Park visit Entrance Fees Peace Museum – 200 JPY

Hiroshima, Miyajima Island, Hiroshima : Known as the ‘romantic shrine Island’ just 1 hour outside of Hiroshima, Miyajima Island makes for the perfect day trip and is home to some of Japan’s best views. Visit the island with your local guide and explore the famous floating Torii Gate and Itsukushima-jinja Shrine. You can hop on the nearby cable car to the top of Mt Misen and embrace the 360-degree views of the inland sea. Enjoy some photo opportunities on the mountain top before returning to Hiroshima with free time in the late afternoon to enjoy the sites of the city. You can also join the optional ropeway. Your guide will be more than happy to offer tips and suggestions on what to see and do during your final night in Hiroshima. Accommodation : Sotetsu Fresa Inn – 4 Star Meals Included : Breakfast Included Activities : Miyajima Island Ferry & Sightseeing Entrance Fees Itsukushima-jinja Shrine – 300 JPY Cable Car to Mt. Misen – 1,000 JPY (one way) Optional Activities Ropeway

Hiroshima, Osaka : Wake up early to hop on a train as we make our way to the city of Osaka. On arrival, make your way to Osaka Castle and explore the surrounding citadels, gates, and impressive stone moats. Continue with a stroll through Osaka’s unmissable Dotombori district to check out the neon-lit canals and try some Japanese-style street food. Spend your afternoon freely to shape your experience to your taste, there is no shortage of things to do in Osaka. Accommodation : Miyako City Hommachi – 4 Star Meals Included : Breakfast Included Activities Osaka Castle Visit Dotonbori Walking Tour

Osaka : Fill up on breakfast because you have a free day to discover Japan’s second-largest metropolitan area at your own pace! This vibrant and eclectic city is the heart and soul of the Kansai region. Explore old backstreets, markets, and retail areas away from tourists; discover the New York-inspired neighbourhood of Shinsekai and sample famous Osaka treats like kushi-katsu and takoyaki octopus balls. Accommodation : Miyako City Hommachi – 4 Star Meals Included : Breakfast

Osaka, Koya-san : Today we will leave Osaka and travel by train and local bus before arriving at Mount Koya. Home to a small mountaintop Buddhist community, Mount Koya (Koyasan) is one of Japan’s most magical destinations. Tonight, we will experience a stay like no other at a traditional Shukubo, a Buddhist Temple lodging. Mount Koya is home to more than 100 temples and monasteries, some of which you will visit with your local guide. The most famous and sacred landmark here is the otherworldly Okunoin Cemetery. Follow your guide as they share stories of the cemetery and explore the location of Kobo Daishi’s (the founder of Shingon Buddhism) mausoleum. Visit the headquarters of Shingon at Kongobuji Temple and marvel at the beautiful Japanese rock gardens while you are here. After a day exploring Mount Koya, we will enjoy an included Shojin Ryori dinner, Buddhist vegeterian cuisine! Accommodation : Houjoin or Sekishouin or Sanboin or Ekoin or Daienin or Saimonin – Ryokan Meals Included : Breakfast, Dinner Included Activities : Mount Koya Monastery Sightseeing Garan Sacred Area Okunoin Cemetery and Kobo Daish Mausoleum Kongobuji Visit Entrance Fees Kongobuji – 1,000 JPY

Koya-san : Wake up early to catch the morning prayer service at your Shukubo lodge. Here you will witness the sacred Goma Ritual where a priest will burn wooden sticks in a fire to destroy negative energies and thoughts while beating the taiko drums and chanting. The ceremony is said to create a trance-like state and have a profound effect on those who witness it – so keep an open mind! Then, hop on a local bus, cable car, and train (approximately 2 hours) as we make our way to the city of Osaka. Enjoy free time in the afternoon to explore Japan’s second-largest metropolitan area. Explore old backstreets, markets, and retail areas away from tourists; discover the New York-inspired neighbourhood of Shinsekai; wander through the flashy, glittering, famed district of Dotonbori; and sample famous Osaka treats like kushi-katsu and takoyaki octopus balls. Accommodation : Candeo Hotel Namba Kishibe or Miyako City Hommachi – 4 Star Meals Included : Breakfast Included Activities : Morning Prayer Ceremony Goma Fire Ceremony

Osaka : Today we saw our goodbyes! Enjoy a final breakfast together before hotel check-out at 10:00. Roam through the backstreets of Osaka one last time before farewelling your new travel mates – until next time! Meals Included : Breakfast

dayInfo.description: Tokyo: Welcome to Tokyo! This afternoon you’ll meet up with your group for a quick trip briefing with your Adventure Leader, who’ll fill you in on everything you need to know and share some great tips for making the most of your time in Japan. Then it’s off to a welcome dinner — the perfect chance to get to know everyone and dig into your first delicious Japanese meal. After dinner, you can hit a local bar with your new travel buddies or call it an early night before the real adventure kicks off tomorrow!

Tokyo: Today kicks off with one of our must-do experiences — a hands-on sushi-making class! Roll up your sleeves, learn the art of sushi from local experts, and then feast on your creations for lunch. In the afternoon, we’ll slow things down with a visit to the peaceful Meiji Shrine, one of Tokyo’s most iconic spots. Dedicated to Emperor Meiji, it’s a beautiful place to reflect and recharge before diving back into the city buzz. Next, we’ll head to Harajuku, Tokyo’s colorful fashion hub where creativity and style know no limits. Wander through quirky backstreets, browse vintage shops, and grab a bite at one of the area’s must-try eateries. Then it’s on to Shibuya Crossing — the busiest intersection in the world! Watch the organized chaos unfold and snap a photo with the famous Hachiko statue before heading off. The rest of the afternoon is yours to explore. Feeling adventurous? Try Kartoon Karting and zip through Tokyo’s streets for a one-of-a-kind experience!

Tokyo: We’ll start the day at Yanaka Ginza, a charming retro shopping street filled with local stalls, quirky shops, and delicious street eats. It’s the perfect place to soak up a slice of everyday Tokyo life and see a more nostalgic side of the city. Next, we head to Akihabara, Japan’s legendary “Electric Town.” This neon wonderland is packed with gaming arcades, anime stores, and gadget shops galore. Challenge your travel crew to a few friendly arcade battles, then experience something truly unique — a visit to one of Akihabara’s famous maid cafés for a fun and picture-perfect taste of Japanese pop culture. From there, we make our way to the historic Asakusa district, home to the iconic Sensoji Temple. Wander down Nakamise-dori, a lively shopping street lined with traditional stalls, before stepping into Tokyo’s oldest Buddhist temple. Later, you’ll have the chance to take part in a special sumo experience — meet ex-wrestlers, learn about the traditions of the sport, and dig into a hearty chanko nabe dinner, the meal that fuels Japan’s sumo champions. The evening is yours to explore. Ask your Adventure Leader for local recommendations or head to Hoppy Street, where cozy izakayas and local brews like doburoku offer the perfect way to toast another incredible day in Tokyo.

Mount Fuji: Today we leave the city behind for a day filled with fresh air, stunning scenery, and traditional charm. Starting from Shinjuku Station, we’ll hop on a train to Shimoyoshida before hiking up to the beautiful Arakura Fuji Sengen Shrine. With its iconic pagoda and postcard-perfect backdrop of Mt Fuji (on a clear day!), it’s one of the most photographed spots in all of Japan — and you’ll quickly see why. Next, we’ll take a short journey to Oshino Hakkai, a peaceful village in the Fuji Five Lakes region. Famous for its crystal-clear ponds fed by Mt Fuji’s snowmelt, this traditional spot feels like stepping back in time. Wander among the thatched-roof houses, enjoy the serene atmosphere, and if the skies are kind, take in some incredible Mt Fuji views. We’ll stop here for lunch and give you time to explore at your own pace. (Please note: Mt Fuji visibility depends on the weather.) In the afternoon, we’ll make our way back to Tokyo, arriving in time for a free evening. It’s your last night in the city — so make it count! Whether that means slurping down one final bowl of ramen, squeezing in some last-minute shopping, or bar hopping with your travel crew, it’s the perfect way to wrap up your Tokyo adventure.

Shimoda: This morning, we say goodbye to Tokyo and make our way to the beautiful coastal town of Shimoda. We’ll stash our bags in lockers and travel light for our overnight stay. We’ll kick things off with a Shimoda Bay Sightseeing Cruise — a short but scenic boat ride offering sweeping views of the coastline and fascinating insights into the port’s history. Keep an eye out for seagulls trailing the boat — you might even get the chance to feed them! Back on land, we’ll take a leisurely stroll along Perry Road, a charming stone-paved street lined with traditional houses, cozy cafés, and quirky local shops. We’ll stop by the Museum of Black Ships (MoBS), which houses more than 3,000 original artifacts that tell the story of Japan’s transition from isolation to international trade. Just nearby is Ryosenji Temple, a peaceful spot where the historic Treaty of Shimoda was signed. After some free time to wander, we’ll take to the skies on the Shimoda Ropeway. From the top, enjoy breathtaking panoramic views of the city, coastline, and surrounding mountains — and if the timing’s right, we might even catch a glowing sunset over the bay. This evening, we’ll settle into our accommodation in Shimoda, where you can unwind with a relaxing onsen soak — the perfect way to end a day by the sea.

Shimoda-Kyoto: This morning, we say farewell to Shimoda and catch the train to Atami. You’ll have some free time here to grab lunch and explore this charming seaside city before we board the iconic shinkansen (bullet train) bound for Kyoto. On arrival, your Adventure Leader will lead a short orientation walk to help you get your bearings and ease into the calm, cultural rhythm of Japan’s former capital. When evening rolls around, it’s time to swap zen for zany! Gather your travel crew and hit up a classic Japanese karaoke spot — belt out your favorite tunes and kick off your stay in Kyoto with a night full of laughter and great vibes.

Kyoto: Today starts with the elegance and mindfulness of a traditional Japanese tea ceremony. Watch as your instructor performs the intricate rituals of preparing and serving matcha, then try your hand at whisking your own bowl of tea. Sweet treats are served alongside, and if you want to go all in, you can even rent a kimono for the full experience. Next, we head to Kiyomizu-dera, one of Japan’s most iconic Buddhist temples and a UNESCO World Heritage site. Take in the sweeping views from its famous wooden stage, then enjoy some free time for lunch at the bustling shops around the temple. In the afternoon, your Adventure Leader will guide you on a short walk through Gion, Kyoto’s historic geisha district. Wander its narrow lanes, peek into traditional tea houses, and admire the wooden machiya architecture. The evening is yours to explore however you like — whether that’s tasting your way through Nishiki Market, browsing the shops along Teramachi, visiting the Samurai Ninja Museum, or catching a performance at the GEAR non-verbal theatre.

Kyoto: This morning is yours to enjoy Kyoto your way. Your Adventure Leader will be on hand via WhatsApp or phone if you need tips or support, but the choice is all yours. You could: Stroll the Philosopher’s Path and admire the serene temples along the way. Head west to Arashiyama for the famous bamboo grove, a hike up to Monkey Park, or a visit to Tenryu-ji Temple. Take a trip to Nara to see the mighty Todaiji Temple and meet the friendly deer in Nara Park. Opt for more cultural experiences in Kyoto, like another tea ceremony, a kimono rental, or a visit to the Ninja and Samurai Museum. Just remember, Kyoto is hugely popular — especially during cherry blossom season — so plan ahead to make the most of your morning. Or simply ask your Adventure Leader for insider tips on hidden gems in the city or even beyond. In the afternoon, we regroup for a hands-on calligraphy class. Guided by a local teacher, you’ll learn the graceful art of Japanese brush writing and create your very own keepsake to take home.

Kyoto-Hiroshima: Get ready for a real Dragon moment! Today we hop on bikes and explore Kyoto like a local. Our half-day ride takes us through the city’s quieter streets and leads to a serene Zen temple, where you’ll join a meditation session led by a Buddhist monk, followed by a calming tea ceremony. After your journey into tranquillity, we pause for a quick lunch before visiting one of Kyoto’s most iconic sights: the Golden Pavilion at Kinkaku-ji. With its shimmering reflection in the surrounding pond, it’s a view you won’t forget. This afternoon, we swap pedals for speed as the shinkansen whisks us west to Hiroshima. After checking in at the hostel, take some time to rest before an evening option to join your group at Okonomiyaki Village, where skilled chefs prepare Hiroshima’s signature dishes right in front of you.

Miyajima & Hiroshima: This morning, we take a train and a short ferry ride out to Miyajima Island, famous for its giant torii gate that appears to float on the sea. At low tide, you can even walk across the sand and stand right beneath this iconic landmark. Next, hop on the Miyajima Ropeway up Mt Misen for incredible panoramic views of the island. Feeling adventurous? You can hike back down through the forest trails, or simply take the ropeway both ways for a more relaxed experience. After some free time for lunch, we return to the mainland and visit the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum and the Atomic Bomb Dome. It’s a moving and powerful experience, offering a deeper understanding of the city’s past and its enduring message of peace. We’ll head back to the hostel in Hiroshima for a free evening — a perfect chance to rest or explore the city at your own pace.

Okayama: This morning, we hop on the shinkansen from Hiroshima to Okayama, where our first stop is the Kurashiki Bikan Quarter. This beautifully preserved Edo-period district is full of charm, with scenic canals, traditional streets, and cozy cafés. Take your time to wander, sample local sweets, and browse the souvenir shops at your own pace. Next, we visit Korakuen Garden, ranked as one of the Three Great Gardens of Japan. With its seasonal blooms, sweeping lawns, and peaceful atmosphere, it’s the perfect place to soak in the beauty of Edo-period landscaping. After collecting our luggage at the station, we continue by shinkansen to Shin-Osaka. Once you’ve dropped off your bags, the evening is yours to enjoy. You can relax after a full day of travel or head out to explore Shinsekai, Osaka’s retro entertainment district. Be sure to try one of the city’s most loved specialties — kushikatsu, skewered and deep-fried delights that are perfect for sharing with your new friends.

Osaka: This morning starts with a short orientation walk to Shinsaibashi, one of Osaka’s liveliest shopping streets. Take some time to wander, soak up the atmosphere, and grab lunch at one of the countless local spots. The rest of the afternoon is yours to explore Osaka at your own pace. You might choose to: Visit the iconic Osaka Castle and enjoy sweeping city views from its tower. Browse, shop, and snack your way through Umeda’s buzzing streets. Step into the National Museum to uncover more of Japan’s rich history and culture. This evening, we gather for a special farewell dinner — the perfect chance to share memories, swap photos, and reflect on the unforgettable journey you’ve had across Japan with your travel crew.

Osaka: All good things must come to an end, and today marks the close of your Japan adventure. Spend the morning saying goodbye to your travel crew and reflecting on the incredible experiences you’ve shared over the past 13 days. Whether you’re off to your next destination or heading home, we hope this journey has given you a true taste of Japan’s culture, contrasts, and unforgettable moments. If you’d like to extend your stay, we can help arrange extra nights in Osaka or a train back to Tokyo — just let us know in advance.

tourName: Family Japan highlights tour on a Shoestring
generalInfo:
Unveil the treasures of Japan as you traverse with your family through a whirlwind of breath taking landscapes and vibrant cityscapes! Start your thrilling adventure in Tokyo, where the neon-lit skyline teems with cutting-edge technology and exquisite cultural experiences. Wander the bustling streets of Shinjuku and Shibuya or find tranquillity amidst the serene beauty of the Meiji Shrine.

Journey onwards to Hakone, your gateway to Mount Fuji's awe-inspiring vistas. Indulge in a rejuvenating soak in the famous hot springs, and sail across the peaceful waters of Lake Ashi with the majestic peak as your backdrop.

Next, immerse yourself in the timeless elegance of Kyoto, a city where ancient traditions flitter through the air like cherry blossoms. Explore the iconic Kinkaku-ji, the Golden Pavilion, or participate in a traditional tea ceremony in the heart of this historic gem.

In Hiroshima, absorb the poignant history and resilience of this city. Pay homage at the Peace Memorial Park and Museum, and witness the rebirth of a locale that stands as a testament to hope and peace.

Conclude your epic journey in Osaka, a dynamic metropolis pulsating with gastronomical delights and lively entertainment. Relish the delicious flavours of street food in Dotonbori, and be swept up in the vibrant atmosphere brimming with bustling energy.
Included is a 1 Day Studio Pass & 1 day Express Pass to Universal Studios Japan.

Embark on this unforgettable adventure to Japan and let its remarkable blend of the ancient and the modern captivate your soul!

We have included connecting rooms where possible but please note that these are subject to avilability and get booked up quickly.

dayInfo.description: Upon arrival in Tokyo, meet our assistant who will provide you with all your train tickets & itinerary. Make your own way to your hotel for the next 3 nights (bed & breakfast).

Embark on a guided half day Tokyo highlights tour by public transport. The day begins with a visit to Asakusa, Tokyo’s old town where you can soak in the atmosphere of traditional Tokyo. Visit Sensoji, Tokyo’s oldest temple, and wander down Nakamise, a shopping street that has been providing temple visitors with a variety of traditional, local snacks and tourist souvenirs for centuries. Travel across town to Omotesando; after exploring the ritzy flagship stores and spectacular architecture on the main boulevard, you will walk up to Meiji Shrine, a shrine dedicated to the deified spirit of Emperor Meiji and a popular place for traditional Japanese weddings.
Day at leisure to explore Tokyo further

Hakone: Travel to Hakone, a natural nature wonderland and is famous for its hot springs, outdoor pursuits and the view of the nearby Mount Fuji. It is part of the Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park and is less than 100-km from Tokyo, thereby providing a popular weekend destination for city residents keen to escape the frenzy of the capital. Beautiful Hakone has about everything a vacationer could wish for. Besides the towering mountains, lakes and views of Mount Fuji, it is also blessed with interesting historical sites. We have included a 2-Day Hakone Free Pass for you to visit the area at leisure. Breakfast & Dinner
Morning at leisure in Hakone and in the afternoon our driver will escort you to the train station to catch the Shinkansen Odawara train to Kyoto.

Kyoto: Guided half day tour of Kyoto From dramatic power struggles that led to almost 200 years of civil war, to the oldest geisha district and its beautifully preserved teahouses, northern Kyoto is rich in history and spectacular architecture. Although this region is home to the most popular tourist site in Kyoto, The Golden Pavilion, many visitors overlook the surrounding neighbourhoods despite their remarkable charm and importance to the city. You’ll find that Kyoto is not only a city steeped in history, but full of modern monks, artisans, baristas, and college students still working towards its lively future. Kinkakuji Temple draws millions of visitors each year, and you will quickly understand why this jewel in the northern hills of Kyoto is one of the country’s most visited sites. Next, stop by Rys reoanji Temple, home to one of the most famous zen rock gardens in Japan. Finally, visit Kitano-Temanngu, a remarkable shrine to scholarship built to appease the spirit of an angry ghost. At the end of the tour, make your own way to your accommodation.
Kyoto: Day at leisure to explore further.

Nara: Travel to Nara to experience Japan's first permanent capital, established in the year 710 at Heijo, the city that is now known as Nara. Nara’s status as the nation’s former capital has left a historical legacy, including some of Japan’s oldest and largest temples. It is a city that still connects with its distinguished past as many of Nara’s historic buildings and temples remain intact and several of these stand in the peaceful confines of a large parkland area, that has the added attraction of free-roaming sacred deer. Bed & Breakfast

Osaka: Commence your journey to Osaka by train and join a guided half day tour in the afternoon. Start your day visiting the magnificent Osaka Castle. The castle is one of Japan's most famous and played a major role in the unification of Japan during the 16th century. Later, walk through Dotonbori, a popular shopping and entertainment district, which is also known as a food destination. At the end of the tour, make your own way to your accommodation. Your hotel in Osaka is for 2 nights, Bed & Breakfast.

Universal Studios Japan: Make your own way to one of Asia's premier theme parks. You will be provided with a Studio Pass and an Express Pass per person to enable you to enjoy a day out at this amazing park.

Hiroshima: make your own way to the station and board your train to Hiroshima. Hiroshima is globally known for its tragic history as the target of the first atomic bomb during the end of World War II. Despite the wide-ranging effects of the bomb dropped over 70 years ago, Hiroshima has recovered as a thriving city and is viewed as a beacon of hope and peace throughout the world. The city centre boasts a large recreational area named Peace Memorial Park that reflects the peaceful aspirations of this reborn city.
Hiroshima: Day at leisure to explore at your own pace.

Please make your own way from your hotel to Hiroshima Station. At Hiroshima Station, you will board the Shinkansen (Bullet train) Hiroshima to Tokyo (Standard Class) Upon arrival at Tokyo Station, please make your own way to you accommodation (Self-arranged transportation). Upon return to Tokyo, your hotel is booked for Bed & Breakfast.
Departure from Japan. Make your own way to the airport

tourName: Golden route tour in Japan, private departure
placesVisited: Tokyo, Hakone, Hiroshima, Miyajima, Kyoto, Nara, Osaka
generalInfo:
Japan’s so-called Golden Route is the best way to introduce yourself to the country if you’ve never been before. Take a journey across Honshu, Japan’s main island and take in the country’s most popular sights.

You’ll fly into Tokyo and spend a mesmerising few days taking in the largest city in the world, and fly out of Osaka at the end of the trip – hopefully after a delicious dose of the city’s famous street food. In between the two, you'll visit the hot spring resorts at Hakone, the rebuilt city of Hiroshima and historic Kyoto.

This is an independent tour, meaning that you’ll travel alone but get full in-country support whenever you need it, plus the help of a tour organiser. You’ll have the use of a pocket WiFi device throughout the trip. This type of tour is perfect for Japan, a country that’s often bewilderingly different for even well-seasoned travellers.

Japan is a country that sits on a knife edge between millennium-old traditions and cutting-edge technology. On one hand: traditional temples, tea ceremonies and sleeping on tatami mats – on the other: street style, skyscrapers and high-speed bullet trains. But to see Japan as a dichotomy is to miss much of it – the gorgeous nature, the peaceful gardens, the tall mountains – and, of course, the food.

dayInfo.description: TOKYO – (no meals) | Your airport pick up will meet you at Narita or Haneda Airport and will take you to your hotel in Tokyo by public transportation. They will validate your JR Rail Passes, make seat reservations, answer any of your questions and hand you your pocket WIFI device to use during your trip. In the evening you will be free to have dinner as you like though your airport pick up will make a few recommendations. The train from Narita Airport to Tokyo Station will take approximately 65 minutes.

TOKYO - (breakfast) | Your private local guide will meet you in the lobby of your hotel and will show you Tokyo. They will take you to sights that interest you and will also make suggestions. We can work on the sightseeing itinerary before you go to Tokyo to better tailor your sightseeing. Some places you might enjoy are Shinjuku, Harajuku, Asakura or many other options. Your guide will also make suggestions for things to do in the evening and the following day.

TOKYO - (breakfast) | One of the best ways to experience a culture is just to wander around and allow things to happen. Your guide from day 2 will give you some suggestions about where to go and what to do. They may even suggest a few places to eat for lunch. For dinner we can arrange for you to have dinner at one of Tokyo's many wonderful restaurants and you may want to try one of their many Michelin starred one.

HAKONE - (breakfast & dinner) | After breakfast you will be going to Hakone, which is one of the finest hot spring resorts in Japan. This area has been popular as a hot spring resort for hundreds of years. Its natural beauty and abundance of hot spring baths make it an ideal spot to relax after spending time in the capital, just as feudal lords did hundreds of years ago. While in Hakone you will have the chance to walk parts of the old Tokaido highway which connected Edo (Tokyo) with Kyoto in times past, ride the scenic Tozan Railway through the mountains, and visit the breathtaking Lake Ashinoko. The train from Tokyo Station to Hakone Yumoto Station will take approximately 1 hour.

HIROSHIMA - ( breakfast) | Hiroshima was the first city to ever experience an atomic bomb which physically destroyed it. The people of Hiroshima, however, rebuilt the city, filling it with charm and history. Hiroshima is also famous for its food, specifically Okonomiyaki which is a must try inexpensive lunch or dinner. While in Hiroshima you can visit the Peace Museum and Park, Shukkeien Garden, or the Hondori Shopping Arcade. The bullet train from Hakone to Hiroshima will take approximately 4 hours and 20 minutes.

MIYAJIMA – (breakfast & dinner) | You will take a train and ferry to Miyajima, which literally means "shrine island", located in the Seto Inland Sea. It is considered to be a sacred place and it provides a stunning example of the ability of the Japanese people to seamlessly blend architecture with natural beauty. Deer and monkeys wander freely around Miyajima, especially on Mt. Misen, the tallest mountain on the island, where there is a good view of the Seto Sea. Here you will stay in a ryokan inn and be served a seafood kaiseki meal featuring oysters from the local sea. The train from Hiroshima Station to Miyajimaguchi Port will take approximately 30 minutes.

KYOTO - (breakfast) | Kyoto, the former imperial capital of Japan, is where the traditional Japanese ‘high arts’ flourished like tea ceremony, calligraphy, poetry, philosophy and religion. Numerous temples and shrines are located throughout the city and walking along canals, next to traditional wooden houses and through the small streets really gives you an idea of the ancient imperial culture. Kyoto also famous for its crafts: textile, kimono and pottery. In Kyoto you can stay in a Ryokan Inn, Hotel or Machiya Townhouse.

KYOTO - (breakfast) | Your private local guide will meet you in the lobby of your hotel and will show you Kyoto. Your guide will take you to Japan's most beautiful and historic temples and shrines, and you will walk down ancient streets where Japanese nobles strolled. There is too much to see and do but you want want to focus on Higashiyama to see Kiyomizudera, Gion to see geisha walking to their next appointment or head north to Kinkakuji. Your guide will work with you so you see the sights you are most interested in visiting. We can work on the sightseeing itinerary before you go to Kyoto to better tailor your sightseeing.

DAY TRIP TO NARA (breakfast) | Nara is located near Kyoto and was the imperial capital from 710 until 784 before it was moved to Heijo-kyo (Kyoto). During this period, a large number of shrines and temples were erected under the protection of the imperial family and aristocrats. However, the monks in the surrounding hills started ro gain too much influence and eventually tried to seize power from the Shinto emperor. It was decided to move the capital to Heian-kyo, nowadays known as Kyoto. Many of the temples built at the height of Nara power, like the Todaiji and Horyuji temples, are currently registered as World Heritage Sites. Both Japanese and foreign tourists visit the city to see these temples, to walk among the free-roaming deer of Nara park or to visit some of the beautiful scenic mountains surrounding the city. You will return to Kyoto for the evening. The train from Kyoto Station to Nara Station will take about 45 minutes.

OSAKA - (breakfast) | Osaka is most famous for its inhabitants and local cuisine. The people of Osaka are widely known for their outgoing spirit and friendliness and the local dialect has been adapted as the standard for stand-up comedians and actors. Osaka’s regional cuisine is thought to be the best in Japan. Dishes include okonomiyaki (a pancake-based dish containing vegetables, meat, and/or seafood), takoyaki (octopus dumplings) and udon noodles. The train from Kyoto to Osaka will take about 40 minutes.

OSAKA - (breakfast) | Your private local guide will meet you in the lobby of your hotel and will show you Osaka. This city is filled with hidden gems that most tourists have no idea they exist like Doguyasuji Street for restaurant owners, Kuromon Ichiba local market street and Amemura. We can work on the sightseeing itinerary before you go to Osaka to better tailor your sightseeing.

DEPART - (breakfast) | Today will be your last day in Japan and your last chance for sightseeing and shopping. You will take a train from Kyoto Station to Kansai Airport following the directions in your tour organizer.

tourName: Hidden Japan holiday
placesVisited: Kyoto, Mount Koya, Shikoku Island, Takamatsu, Naoshima island, Kotohira and Kompira-san shrine, Iya Valley, Miyajima, Stay in ryokan traditional inn with hot spring bath.
generalInfo:
If you're curious about the quieter, more traditional side of the country – from mountain temples to art islands and ryokan inns – Hidden Japan might just be your perfect tour. A decade in the making, Hidden Japan reveals the country’s lesser-travelled paths – where small communities offer big welcomes, and traditions thrive beyond the cities.

Trip Overview:
• Kyoto – In Gion, share tea and conversation with a trainee geisha (maiko) in a rare, Insider guide-arranged meeting.
• Mount Koya – Stay in temple lodgings, join morning prayers, and explore the Okunoin cemetery with 200,000 tombstones – the resting place of monks, shogun, and revered 8th century priest Kobo Daishi
• Tokushima – Witness (and join in with!) the exuberant Awa Odori festival dance and catch a bunraku puppet theatre show
• Takamatsu & Naoshima – Stroll Ritsurin Garden’s winding paths and take the ferry to Naoshima art island, home to world-class installations and striking architecture (it’s not just about those beach pumpkins)
• Kotohira – Climb 785 steps to Konpira-san Shrine, go beneath the boards of one of Japan’s oldest kabuki theatres, and relax in an open-air rotenburo bath, looking out over the mountainside.
• Iya Valley – Walk across vine bridges, cruise between the jagged cliffs of the Oboke Gorge, and explore the somewhat creepy, yet cute, Yokai Monster Museum
• Matsuyama – Visit one of 12 remaining original samurai castles and bathe at Dogo Onsen, the inspiration for Spirited Away
• Hiroshima & Miyajima – Reflect at the Peace Memorial Museum, taste local okonomiyaki, and visit Miyajima’s floating torii gate and roaming deer

Dietary requirements
We can cater for vegetarian diets on all of our Small Group Tours. Vegan diets can usually be accommodated, though options may be more limited on certain itineraries, particularly in remote areas where meals are provided by local accommodations. In these cases, vegan travellers should expect simpler meals than the standard offering, but we’ll always do our best to make it work.

Tour highlights
• Meet a maiko (geisha in training) in the historic district of Gion, for tea, games and a chance to ask questions
• Visit Naoshima art island
• Explore Iya Valley: cruise through the jagged cliffs of Oboke Gorge (you may spot a macaque monkey or two)
• Visit Hiroshima – learn about its tragic past, but also experience its modern, forward-looking energy and try their version of okonomiyaki (a delicious savoury pancake)
• Connect with the community of Joge through a kendo lesson and browsing family-owned stalls
• Stay on Mount Koya, the centre of Shingon Buddhism, in a traditional temple lodging. Rise early for morning prayers with the resident monk.
• Climb the 785 steps to Konpira-san Shrine, then soak in your own hot spring rotenburo bath in Kotohira
• See one of Japan's 12 surviving original samurai castles – Matsuyama Castle
• Meet the Miyajima island deer

dayInfo.description: KYOTO (dinner) Arrive at Kansai International Airport (KIX) or Osaka International Airport (ITM). You’ll be met by our representative and take taxi to your hotel in Kyoto. That evening, you'll meet your fellow travellers at a welcome meeting and dinner (included) at a nearby restaurant.

KYOTO (breakfast) | Kyoto isn’t called the “City of Ten Thousand Temples” for nothing, and today the tour leader will lead a full day tour of the best temples the city has to offer. Of course, if you’d rather go off and explore on your own, your tour leader will be happy to offer suggestions. In the afternoon, you’ll visit a traditional tea house in the Gion geisha district area for a private audience with an apprentice geisha (maiko).

MT KOYA (breakfast, lunch & dinner) | Today you’ll venture off the beaten path, heading up to Mount Koya, a remote mountaintop temple community and the spiritual home of Shingon Buddhism. Mount Koya is located deep in the mountains of Wakayama Prefecture and is home to a collection of ancient temples, shrines and pagodas – not to mention Okunoin, the largest cemetery in Japan. A local guide will join us to explain the history and significance of these sites. We’ll stay in temple lodgings, complete with authentic Buddhist vegetarian meals (multi-course, intricately presented kaiseki) – an unforgettable experience.

TOKUSHIMA | Before breakfast, you’ll have the chance to join the morning ceremonies at our temple lodgings. Our clients tell us this is a really special moment: feeling part of ancient rituals carried out by the temple monks. After prayers, you’ll have a traditional Buddhist breakfast before jumping on a private bus to Wakayama Port for the short ferry crossing to Tokushima, on Shikoku Island. Tokushima famous for Awa Odori – the largest dance festival in Japan. You’ll visit the Awa Odori Kaikan Museum for some background on the festival, see a performance (where audience participation is encouraged) and ride the cable car to the top of Mount Bizan for some truly fantastic views out across the city and the surrounding countryside and mountains.

TAKAMATSU (breakfast) | After breakfast, you’ll take a half day trip to the Awa Jurobe Yashiki theatre, a chance to see a traditional bunraku puppet theatre performance in an authentic setting. You’ll then make your way to Takamatsu, where you’ll spend the afternoon wandering Risturin Gardens, one of the best landscape gardens in Japan, and yet lesser visited than others.

NAOSHIMA (breakfast) | The group takes a full day trip to the nearby 'art island' of Naoshima, packed with art galleries and outdoor installations. A local guide will explain the history of the island's art projects and introduce us to some of its most impressive and lesser-known sights. You’ll have lunch at Benesse House Museum, a renowned gallery housing works by famous artists from Claude Monet to Yayoi Kusama. In the evening you’ll return to your Takamatsu hotel.

KOTOHIRA (breaksfast & dinner) | After breakfast you'll make the scenic train ride from Takamatsu to Kotohira, known as the location of Shikoku's largest shrine complex – Konpira-san. If you’ve got the energy, scale the 1,368 steps to Konpira-san's inner shrine, well worth the effort for the far-reaching views. You’ll stay at a ryokan hotel with its own hot spring baths with Japanese-style evening meals included on both nights.

IYA VALLEY (breakfast, lunch & dinner) | Board a private bus bound for the Iya Valley, a lush and undeveloped area of natural beauty, particularly famous for its vine bridges. Today we'll cross one of these bridges, have a traditional Japanese lunch and take a boat ride through jagged cliffs of the Oboke Gorge. You’ll pay a visit to a rural ex-samurai residence before returning to Kotohira, where a second night of hot spring baths and a classically Japanese meal awaits.

MATSUYAMA (breakfast) | A train ride west across the island of Shikoku will bring you to Matsuyama, home to Dogo Onsen, the oldest hot spring baths in Japan. These baths date back more than 3,000 years (though the current buildings were completed in 1894) and there’s even a set of baths reserved exclusively for the imperial family. Matsuyama is home to one of the best original samurai castles in Japan: you’ll have time to explore the donjon (main keep) and museum before taking a dip in the restorative hot spring waters.

HIROSHIMA From Matsuyama you’ll take the jet foil ferry across the Seto Inland Sea to Hiroshima back on mainland Japan. Hiroshima will always be remembered for the tragic events of 1945, and you’ll visit the inspiring Peace Park and sobering Peace Memorial Museum for an insight into the dropping of the world's first atomic bomb. Informative and even-handed, this museum is a must-see. After a thought-provoking afternoon, you’ll experience modern-day Hiroshima, where you can walk along the river or hit the lively Hondori shopping arcade. This evening, you’ll sample Hiroshima’s speciality dish: okonomiyaki, a savoury pancake layered with toppings and a delicious sauce.

HIROSHIMA (breakfast) | Today is free time. You could opt to join your Insider guide on a day trip to Miyajima – a tiny island known for its friendly, free-roaming deer and “floating” torii gate – Itsukushima Shrine – considered one of Japan's three most iconic views. If you’re feeling energetic, you can hike to the top of Mount Misen for a panoramic coastal view (alternatively, you can catch the cable car!)

KYOTO (breakfast) | On the way back to Kyoto, you’ll stop off in Joge – a rural town in Hiroshima prefecture. You’ll meet the local community, taking part in a kendo fencing lesson and visiting the wonderfully preserved Zen temple and kabuki theatre. There’s lunch at a local restaurant. Then, it's all aboard the super-fast Shinkansen (bullet train) for your trip back to Kyoto for the final night and farewell dinner with your tour leader and group.
DEPART (breakfast) | Say goodbye and transfer by private taxi to the airport for your flight home, or, the next leg of your Japan or Asia adventure.

tourName: Highlights of Japan holiday, Kyushu Island
generalInfo:
Discover a side of Japan that few travellers reach. Our brand-new nine-day Kyushu adventure takes you to the country's third-largest island, where dramatic landscapes, bubbling hot springs and rich culture await. Explore the vibrant cities of Fukuoka and Nagasaki, enjoy an overnight stay in a traditional ryokan, and sample the region's famous tonkotsu ramen. There's even a chance to see one of the world's largest volcanic caldera - an awe-inspiring natural wonder.

Aso-Kuju National Park - Discover stunning volcanic landscapes, steaming hot springs, virgin forests and grasslands
Hot Spring havens - Relax in the hot spring towns of Beppu and Kurokawa Onsen, famous for their therapeutic waters
Gateways to the West - Uncover the cultural and historical heritage of Nagasaki, Kumamoto, and Fukuoka
Extend your stay? - Visit the highlights of Honshu Island on our 14 day Simply Japan trip in combination with this trip

dayInfo.title: Join Tour in Fukuoka
dayInfo.description: : Our tour starts today in Fukuoka on Kyushu Island, Japan's third-largest island and the historic gateway to Asia. This southernmost island of the mainland is influenced by a long history of contact with the rest of Asia and the West. Fukuoka is the largest city and a hotspot of culture, art, history and food. This is a great place to start our exploration of northern Kyushu, through a landscape of dramatic mountains, volcanic terrain, varied hot springs and peaceful beaches. Fukuoka is known as one of the top destinations in Japan for delicious food. While the seafood and vegetables are excellent, the city is also famous for its chicken dishes. Local specialties include mizutaki (a hot pot made with chicken) and yakitori (grilled chicken skewers). The city also has a great street food scene, and one dish that has gone global is tonkotsu ramen - a local variation on a famous noodle dish. If you are arriving early, you may choose to visit the Kyushu National Museum or Fukuoka Tower. For those arriving on time, our tour leader plans to meet you in the hotel reception at 6pm for a welcome meeting, with the chance to go out afterwards with the rest of the group for dinner. If some of the group are arriving on later flights, the main introductory briefing will take place on the morning of Day 2 with everybody present. There are no activities planned today, so you're free to arrive at any time. If you miss the welcome meeting, your tour leader will inform you of any essential information as soon as you catch up. We don't provide arrival transfers on this tour, but information on how to reach the hotel will be provided in your final documentation. Fukuoka Airport (FUK) is around 20 minutes away from the hotel by metro or slightly longer by a relatively inexpensive taxi, depending on traffic. If you're joining this trip after participating in one of our other trips that end on Honshu Island, such as Simply Japan, you can either make your own way to Fukuoka or contact us to put you in touch with our local partners who will help arrange your train ticket.

dayInfo.title: Explore Fukuoka City by public transport
dayInfo.description: : Our adventure kicks off after breakfast this morning. First, we take the train out of town to the peaceful grounds of the Shinto shrine of Dazaifu Tenmangu. Hundreds of Tenmangu shrines exist across Japan, dedicated to the exiled scholar Michizane and, among these, two reign supreme - one in Kyoto and this one in Fukuoka, which is built atop his grave. Thousands of plum trees are planted here, adding to the natural beauty. After heading back into town, we explore Ohori, a scenic city park with a large pond, which was once part of the moat system of a castle. After an included tonkotsu ramen lunch, we continue to Tochoji Temple, home to Japan's largest seated Buddha, and Jotenji Temple - the birthplace of udon and soba noodles. We end today's tour with a glimpse into traditional life, crafts and culture in the Meiji and Taisho eras at the Hakata Machiya Folk Museum, which focuses on the houses from that period. Fukuoka is well known for its open-air food stalls (Yatai), and tonight we recommend trying some of them out. They're not suitable for a group meal as they can only seat a few people, so we suggest splitting up into mini groups or exploring on your own. There are dozens across town, your tour leader will be able to advise you on which ones you should visit - there are several which are centrally located, as well as some situated along the water on the southern end of Nakasu Island. Depending on how many of the group arrive in time for the day 1 meeting, your Tour Leader may arrange a group meal tonight and advise Yatai stalls for the first night.

dayInfo.title: Train to Nagasaki. Discover the Dutch trading quarter of Dejima and the Peace Park Memorial and Museum
dayInfo.description: : We have a busy day ahead today as we set off on our travels around Kyushu. First, we take the bullet train to Nagasaki - a journey of around one hour and a half. Nagasaki is an important deep harbour city with an eventful history and was, of course, the target of the second atomic bomb attack on Japan. Our first visit is to the poignant and moving Peace Park and Museum, a memorial site dedicated to the victims of the 1945 atomic bombing, which symbolises the hope for world peace and the abolition of nuclear weapons. The city was, for long periods in its history, Japan's main contact with the outside world. In the 16th century, it was established as the main trade point with the Portuguese. As well as providing wealth from trade, the Portuguese introduced Christianity. After almost a century of turmoil, the religion was banned, foreign traders were expelled, and Japan closed its doors to the West. The one exception was the artificial island in Nagasaki harbour, Dejima. This small, closely guarded enclave was the site of the Dutch Trading Mission, which remained Japan's only contact with the outside world for almost 200 years. During our visit here and to the residential quarters of Glover Gardens this afternoon, we'll see that some of the original features remain, as well as some excellent reconstructions of the 18th-century buildings. We also plan to visit Oura Cathedral, Japan's oldest standing Christian church and a UNESCO World Heritage site. Our hotel isn't located in this area, so we'll stop for a group dinner in Dejima, for those who want to join, straight after our tour. This evening, you have the optional opportunity to catch one of the 'three greatest nighttime views in Japan' from Mount Inasa - wait until night falls and then take the cable car, which is just a few minutes' walk from our hotel. Please note, our main luggage will be forwarded to our hotel in Kumamoto today, and we'll be travelling with just our overnight bags. Depending on local arrangements, you might need to leave your luggage in reception the night of Day 2 or before breakfast this morning - your tour leader will advise you on the time. For more information, please refer to the Budgeting & packing section of the Trip Information.

dayInfo.title: Train and ferry to Kumamoto. Visit Kumamoto Castle, built by a samurai warlord
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we make our way to Shimabara Port by local train (a two hour journey), where we ride the ferry (a one-hour journey), then a local bus bound for Kumamoto, a major city rich in samurai history located on the west coast of Kyushu Island. After some free time for lunch, our first visit is to the former residence of Lafcadio Hearn, a Greek-born American writer who ended up living here and helped introduce the culture and literature of Japan to the West. Panoramic views await us from the City Hall Observation Deck. Kumamoto Castle is considered to be one of the three most impressive in Japan, and after our visit, we have some free time at Sakura-no-baba Josaien - a complex of shops selling crafts, souvenirs and local produce designed to look like a traditional walled castle town.

dayInfo.title: Scenic charter bus journey across Aso-Kuju National Park to Kurokawa Onsen village
dayInfo.description: : Over the next two days, we'll traverse the dramatic volcanic landscapes of northern Kyushu by charter bus. At times, we'll be travelling through Aso-Kuju National Park - a dynamic landscape with volcanic peaks, hot springs, virgin forests and vast grasslands. The southern part of the park is dominated by Mount Aso, one of the world's largest calderas with five peaks within it that are said to resemble a sleeping Buddha. This morning, we plan to visit Aso Sanjo Shrine, located high up Mt Aso, enshrining a volcanic crater. Kamishikimi Kumanomimasu shrine offers a contrasting setting amid the forest, and we access it on a stone staircase through sacred torii gates. For over a millennium, the park's grasslands have been seared away in a controlled burn from mid-February to March. This helps preserve the grasslands for cattle and horses. Parts of the caldera and national park are 'regular sections' where inhabitants farm and graze the rich soils, and we plan to stop at the Aso Milk factory, famous in Japan for its high-quality milk and cheese products. Our journey continues this afternoon with a stop at the Daikanbo Lookout for commanding views over the caldera. Our final stop is at the ancient and revered Aso Shrine before we continue to our nightstop in the attractive hot spring town of Kurokawa Onsen. This resort town has managed to maintain a pleasant, traditional atmosphere, and we recommend a walk through town in yukata and geta sandals to explore the lanes lined with wooden buildings, ryokan, onsen (public bath houses), shops and cafes. In Kurokawa Onsen we stay in traditional Japanese-style accommodation. The rooms are twin-share or single with traditional tatami-mat (woven soft 'igusa' straw) flooring and futons to sleep on. Generally, the rooms are simply decorated with a low 'kotatsu' table to sit around and a scroll or picture in an alcove. Shoes are removed at the entrance and are not permitted anywhere within the accommodation. There are shared toilets and traditional baths. The shower in the bathing area is used to cleanse before a relaxing soak. Please note that, due to the small size of each accommodation here, the group will be spread out over several Ryokan. In cases of limited availability this overnight stay may be in another location in the wider Aso-Kuju area, or alternatively in a hotel accommodation in Kurakawa Onsen. Please also note that occasional volcanic activity may cause changes to our planned itinerary - our tour leader will inform you of any necessary changes.

dayInfo.title: Scenic drive to Beppu via Nabegataki Falls, a Taiko drum performance and the Tadewara marshes
dayInfo.description: : Continuing our journey across Kyushu today, we'll make several stops at places of interest along the way. Our first visit is along a 1-kilometre/0.6-mile trail that leads us to Nabegataki Falls, a 10-metre/33-foot high waterfall with access to the cavern behind the falls. Next up we'll make a stop at Kokonoe Yume Otsuribashi - a dramatic footbridge that traverses the panoramic scenery of a remote forested valley. The taiko drum has been part of the Japanese culture for centuries, used at different times in communication, military and religious ceremonies. This afternoon, if the weather allows, we plan to see a taiko drum performance on an open-air stage against a dramatic backdrop. Please note that this will not always be possible from January to March as the group performs only occasionally through these months. The order of visits today may vary according to local conditions and daylight hours. Tadewara is one of two protected marshes at the edge of the Kuju mountain range, which runs through the centre of the National Park. It is home to a variety of rare plants as well as birdlife, and we will spend some time walking the elevated cedar boardwalks to explore these marshlands. Finally, we reach our hotel in Beppu, where we'll spend the next two nights. With over 2,000 hot springs, Beppu is one of Japan's most famous hot spring resorts, and only Yosemite produces more. Despite being heavily geared up for tourism, Beppu is still a place of interest and worthy of inclusion in the itinerary. Please note, our main luggage will be forwarded to our hotel in Fukuoka for our arrival on Day 8, and we'll be travelling with just our bags for the next couple of nights. Depending on local arrangements, you might need to leave your luggage in reception the night of Day 5 or before breakfast this morning - your tour leader will advise you on the time. For more information, please refer to the Budgeting & packing section of the Trip Information.

dayInfo.title: Explore the colourful hot springs of Beppu. Steam-cooked local lunch
dayInfo.description: : Beppu is Japan's hot spring capital with eight major springs and some 3,000 vents - you'll be able to see and smell the sulphurous steam rising across this resort city. This morning we will visit some of the popular and colourful hot springs in what is locally known as a hell tour - including Sea Hell (Umi Jigoku), Cooking Pot (Kamado Jigoku), Blood Pond Hell (Chinoike Jigoku) and depending on the time of your visit you may be lucky enough to see a Geyser erupting. For lunch today, we've planned jigoku-mushi or 'hell steaming'. With the help of a local guide, we'll source our ingredients from the local market and shops before cooking over the natural geothermal steam. Then, this afternoon, we'll visit Myoban Yunosato, a hot spring with views over Beppu. The yu-no-hana thatch-roof huts here continue to make bathing salts in the traditional method, maintaining 300 years of Edo-period craftsmanship. The rest of the late afternoon is free for you to explore solo. Takegawara Onsen was built in 1879 and is one of the oldest and most famous, so you may wish to visit to see the distinctive architecture and perhaps even have a communal hot bath or a sand bath.

dayInfo.title: Visit the traditional castle town of Kitsuki on train route back to Fukuoka
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we leave Beppu and take the local express train to the former castle town of Kitsuki - a hidden gem in Oita, which is known by locals but more rarely touched by foreign tourists. We've planned a short walking tour with a local guide to explore the samurai townscape, seaside castle setting and streets infused with the Edo-era and four historic artisan shops - accessible only with a local guide. The tour includes a rare magewappa (woodcraft) workshop run by one of only two remaining craftsmen in Kyushu, a miso brewery founded in 1900, a traditional tea shop from the mid-Edo period, and a sake brewery established in 1874 with multiple awards. Enjoy tastings of miso, matcha and sake. This is a rare opportunity to experience over a century of craftsmanship and tradition. After some free time for lunch here, we'll return to Fukuoka by express train (a journey of around two hours). We'll check into our hotel, and the rest of the afternoon is free for last-minute shopping or sightseeing before our final supper and a chance to reflect on the holiday.

dayInfo.title: Tour ends in Fukuoka
dayInfo.description: : The trip ends after breakfast at our hotel in Fukuoka. There are no activities planned today, so you\ re free to depart from Fukuoka at any time. If your flight is departing later in the day, luggage storage facilities are available at our hotel. If you\ d like an airport transfer today, you'll need to depart from Fukuoka Airport (FUK), which is around 20 minutes away from the hotel. The transfer will be by metro, and our tour leader will give you your ticket and clear instructions so you can travel unescorted.

tourName: Highlights of Japan holiday
generalInfo:
From the bright lights of Tokyo to the tranquil temples of Kyoto, this fast-paced tour packs in Japan's highlights. Sample street food in Osaka, take time to reflect at Hiroshima, the site of the world's first atomic attack, and visit the holy island of Miyajima, dotted with temples and free-roaming deer. Along the way, tick off Japan's must-dos travelling via bullet train and trying izakaya-style cuisine.

Tokyo - Get to grips with Japan's ultra-modern capital and explore the traditional temples of Asakusa.

Kyoto - Spend a full day discovering the temples and gardens of Japan's Imperial Capital.

Jigokudani Onsen - Catch a glimpse of the famous snow monkeys bathing in hot springs.

dayInfo.title: Tour begins in Tokyo
dayInfo.description: : Our tour starts today in Tokyo, Japan's ultra-modern capital. A sprawling metropolis, Tokyo is one of the world's most populous cities and a dazzling blend of traditional culture and all things new. For those arriving in time, our tour leader plans to meet you in the hotel reception at 6.30pm for a welcome meeting. If some of the group are arriving on later flights, the main introductory briefing will take place on the morning of Day 2 with everybody present. After the meeting, we'll have dinner (included) at a nearby local restaurant where you'll have the chance to try 'izakaya' style Japanese cuisine. There are no other activities planned today, so you're free to arrive in Tokyo at any time. If you'd like an airport transfer today, you'll need to arrive into Haneda Airport (HND) or Narita Airport (NRT). The city centre is around an hour away from Haneda and an hour and a half from Narita. Should you miss the welcome meeting, your tour leader will inform you of any essential information as soon as you catch up. The Tour Leader will issue each client with a Suica transport card either today or tomorrow morning, that is pre-loaded to cover your included sightseeing public transport journeys. Please note, while our itinerary gives us a full day in Japan's capital, there's a lot to pack in. If you really want to get to grips with Tokyo's sites, we recommend adding additional nights to your trip pre-tour. Japanese hotels have strict rules regarding check in and all customers are required to wait until 3 PM for room access. You will be able to store your luggage while waiting but if you require an early check in, then you should request this at the time of booking. We do not guarantee this will be possible and depending on availability an extra fee will be charged.

dayInfo.title: Explore Tokyo’s neon streets and peaceful gardens
dayInfo.description: : Over one-quarter of the Japanese population lives within a 50-kilometre/31-mile radius of the centre of Tokyo, making it the most populous metropolitan area in the world. The result is a bustling and exciting city - an economic powerhouse of Asia. However, scratching its neon-clad surface reveals a city bursting with history and tradition. A morning stroll to Tokyo's oldest temple, Sensoji, will introduce us to Tokyo's unique culture. We'll then board a boat for a short journey along the Sumida River. Gaining a totally different perspective of the city, we'll drift past high-rise apartments, secluded gardens and busy warehouses. Arriving in the heart of the city, we'll visit Hamarikyu Gardens. The rest of the day is left free, and you might like to board a train to visit the Meiji shrine and Shinjuku area, where the latest electronic gadgets dazzle from glowing shopfronts.

dayInfo.title: Bullet train to Kanazawa via the snow monkeys of Jigokudani
dayInfo.description: : No trip to Japan would be complete without a journey on a high-speed train and this morning we leave Tokyo and board the Shinkansen. Our main bags will be forwarded to Osaka today and we'll make do with an overnight bag for tonight. The bullet trains are known for their extremely punctual service, comfortable carriages, and lack of noise as you travel at speeds of up to 300 kilometres/186 miles per hour. Alighting at Nagano in the Japanese Alps, we'll make our way by private coach to Jigokudani Onsen, home to Japan's famous snow monkeys. Here the indigenous macaques descend from the hills to bathe and play in the hot springs, a unique behaviour not found anywhere else in the world. Despite their wintry moniker, the monkeys can be observed in and around the pool throughout the year (although sightings are more likely in colder months). Our walk to the spring takes 30 minutes along a pretty forest trail which is mostly flat with some steep stairs and narrow sections. Once at the spring, we'll spend around an hour observing the monkeys before returning along the same path. Leaving Nagano behind, we'll head for Kanazawa, which until 150 years ago was the 4th largest city in Japan. The city has shunned mass industrialisation and retains its traditional charm with its winding back streets, delicate tea shops and the beautiful autumn maples and spring cherry blossoms of Kenrokuen Gardens.
