Your leader will take you on a hike up the hill, away from most of the crowds, so you can get the best views and most peaceful feel of the place. Later, visit to the historic Gion area, where you might spot a geisha.

dayInfo.title: Kyoto (Hiking).
dayInfo.description: Head with your group to Ginkakuji, also known as the Silver Pavilion. Built more than 500 years ago, this structure is surrounded by intricate Japanese landscape architecture and was modelled off the Golden Pavilion, Kinakuji. From Ginkakuji, you’ll hike up Mt Daimonji-yama – one of the best short hikes in Kyoto. From the top, you’ll get a panoramic view of the city and on a clear day, all the way over to Yoshida-yama Hill. When you’re back in town, the afternoon is yours to choose your own adventure. Maybe check out Kyoto’s Kitchen at Nishiki food markets, visit Nijo Castle and the Imperial Palace, or get lost in the zigzagging lanes of the traditional Ninen-zaka and Sannen-zaka districts. If you prefer a bit of relaxation, rest up in one of the sentos (traditional bath houses) in the city – a must-do experience at least once in Japan!

dayInfo.title: Kyoto (Cycling).
dayInfo.description: Today it’s time to jump back on two wheels. Pick up your rental bikes and start exploring Kyoto. Cycle along the beautiful Kamogawa River to Demachiyanangi, stopping at Daitokuji Temple. Learn about Zen Buddhism and find a dose of peace before hopping back on the saddle and continuing to the Kinkakuji Temple – also known as the Golden Pavilion. Heading back along Kamogawa River, finish your cycling adventure and head back to the bike shop. Tonight you’re free to find the best feed – your leader always has the best recommendations!

dayInfo.title: Shingu/Koguchi.
dayInfo.description: This morning, hop on the train to Shingu. Visit Kumano Hayatama Taisha Shrine – one of the three main shrines part of the Kumano Kodo network. After you've had a look around, visit Kamikura Shrine – one of the oldest and most sacred shrines in Shingu. This shrine has a stunning view over Shingu city out to the Pacific Ocean. Change to a local public bus to Koguchi, where you’ll have dinner and rest for the night to get ready for tomorrow's hike.

dayInfo.title: Koguchi/Kii Katsuura (Hiking).
dayInfo.description: Today is an early start as you head out to hike part of the famous Kumano Kodo – one of the only two UNESCO World Heritage-listed pilgrim routes in the world. The Kumano Kodo is a network of ancient routes that connect three major religious sites – known collectively as the Kumano Sanzan. Throughout the centuries, the pilgrim route has been used by imperial families, nobility, warriors and common folk alike as part of their spiritual practice. For the first couple of hours it's an uphill climb that rises over 800 m. After reaching the Echizen-toge Pass, follow the forest ridge for another couple of kilometres until you reach the highest point – Funami-jaya teahouse at 868 m. From here, head mostly downhill to Nachi Taisha – another of the three Kumano shrines. See the Nachi Falls along the way, too, then take a bus down to Kii Katsuura for the night.

dayInfo.title: Toba.
dayInfo.description: Take the train to Toba today. Toba is the perfect place to wind down after a few days of hiking, cycling and kayaking. When you arrive, your leader will take you on a short orientation walk in the old town of Toba and give you the option to have a fresh seafood barbecue for lunch – oysters, anyone? In the afternoon, visit the famous Mikimoto Pearl Island Museum. Toba's claim to fame is it’s the birthplace of the cultured pearl industry and here, you'll be able to witness how Ama divers (female pearl divers) collect pearls in the traditional way. In the evening, maybe check out the onsen in your hotel – there's no better way to relax tense muscles than soaking yourself in the hot springs with an amazing view over the bay area ahead.

dayInfo.title: Osaka.
dayInfo.description: In the morning, hop back on the train and return to Osaka. Arrive at around lunch time and go on a walking tour with your leader to the famous Dotombori district, which is popular for its shopping, food and entertainment. At night, this place is lit by hundreds of neon lights and signs, including the famous Glico Running Man sign and Kani Doraku crab sign. If the mood strikes, why not join your group for a final dinner at one of the many amazing restaurants and toast to a trip well travelled!

dayInfo.title: Osaka.
dayInfo.description: There are no activities planned after breakfast today and your adventure comes to an end. You're free to leave at any time after check out. If you'd like to extend your stay, just get in touch with your booking agent ahead of time to organise additional accommodation.

tourName: Japan adventure holiday on a budget
generalInfo:
This 11-night adventure is designed for two travelers , seamlessly blending the country's futuristic modernity with its rich, ancient traditions. From the neon-lit excitement of Tokyo to the profound history of Hiroshima and the serene temples of Kyoto, this tour offers an in-depth, immersive cultural experience.

Experience the Magic of Contrast

Tokyo's Dynamic Energy: You will arrive in Tokyo, a city often called the world's largest , and experience its vibrant blend of modernity and tradition. The city is known for its futuristic skyscrapers, neon lights, and peaceful shrines.

Unique Culinary Adventures: Dive into Tokyo's world-renowned culinary scene with two dedicated food tours: a thrilling Tokyo night food tour in Shinjuku , where you'll hunt for hidden local eateries and enjoy a Sushi set and Wagyu Japanese BBQ , and a morning Tsukiji Fish Market Food and Walking Tour to explore one of the world's largest seafood markets and its rich 80-year history.

Spiritual and Natural Majesty: Witness the stunning beauty of nature and spirituality on a private day trip to Mt. Fuji and Hakone. You'll get breathtaking views of the snow-capped Mount Fuji , explore the sacred Kitaguchi Hongu Fuji Sengen Shrine , and take in panoramic vistas from the Mount Fuji Panoramic Ropeway.

A Journey of Peace and Resilience: Reflect on a defining moment of world history in Hiroshima with a Peace Cycling Tour. You will cycle past A-bomb heritage sites , visit the Atomic Bomb Dome , and witness the city's transformation into a cosmopolitan symbol of peace and hope.

Ancient Cultural Capital: Immerse yourself in Kyoto , the former imperial capital, referred to as Japan’s cultural and spiritual heart. You will walk through the iconic Arashiyama Bamboo Forest , explore the UNESCO World Heritage Tenryuji Temple , and hike up to the Iwatayama Monkey Park. You'll also delve into traditional Japanese culture with a Kyoto Gion Night Walk in the famous geisha district , hoping to catch a glimpse of a geiko or maiko.

HIGH AND LOW SEASON IN JAPAN

Japan has several high seasons, when crowds and prices are generally elevated. These include:

Spring (Mid-March to Mid-May): Encompasses the cherry blossom season and Golden Week.

Autumn Leaves Season (Mid-November to Early December): Drawn by the stunning fall foliage, this is a very popular time for both domestic and international tourists, especially in spots like Kyoto.

Summer Vacation (Mid-July to August): Includes the Obon holiday (mid-August), a traditional time for family reunions and travel, leading to increased domestic travel.

New Year's (Late December to Early January): A major holiday period with high demand for travel, although some businesses and tourist sites may be closed.

dayInfo.description: Your Japanese adventure begins as you arrive at Narita International Airport (NRT) and take a smooth train transfer to the bustling heart of Tokyo. Settle into your hotel and prepare to experience one of the world's most dynamic capital cities, where ancient tradition meets futuristic innovation.

As night falls, immerse yourself in the world of authentic Japanese cuisine on a Tokyo night food tour in Shinjuku. Accompanied by a local guide, you’ll navigate the largest dining district, moving beyond the crowds to find hidden gems. Your dinner is a feast of old-fashioned Japanese cuisine, featuring a traditional Sushi set and a chance to prepare your own famous Wagyu Japanese BBQ. The night culminates in the bustling, neon-lit Kabuki-Cho area with a final drink or dessert.

Uncover Tokyo's dynamic blend of past and present on a full-day private walking tour. Your journey starts in the swirling energy of the Shibuya Crossing. Transition to the quiet significance of the Imperial Palace, home of Japan's emperor. Step back in time at Senso-ji Temple, the city’s oldest and most revered temple, before wandering the peaceful, war-surviving streets of Yanaka. Conclude your day with sweeping panoramic views of the impressive skyline from the Tokyo Tower observation deck.

Start your day with an immersive exploration of the Tsukiji Fish Market Food and Walking Tour. This iconic market has shaped Tokyo's culinary scene for over 80 years. Your journey begins with a moment of tranquility at Tsukiji Hongwanji, a magnificent Buddhist temple. Then, dive into the bustling Tsukiji Outer Market, where colorful stalls brim with fresh seafood and traditional ingredients. Your local expert will share the fascinating history and deep-rooted culinary significance of the market.

Check out of Tokyo and embark on a thrilling private sightseeing day trip to the area surrounding Mt. Fuji and Hakone. Your adventure begins with unparalleled views of Mount Fuji from Arakurayama Sengen Park, followed by a visit to the spiritual sanctuary of Kitaguchi Hongu Fuji Sengen Shrine. You'll travel halfway up the iconic mountain to the 5th Station for breathtaking vistas. The tour continues to the picturesque Lake Kawaguchi, famous for reflecting Mount Fuji, and includes a ride on the Panoramic Ropeway. Conclude your day strolling through Oishi Park and the traditional village of Oshino Hakkai. You will then be transferred to your charming, mountain-area accommodation in Hakone.

Enjoy a well-deserved day at leisure in the mountainous and serene region of Hakone. This area is famous for its natural hot springs (onsens), stunning lakes, and views of Mount Fuji. Use this day to relax, explore the local art museums, or simply soak in the tranquility of the Japanese countryside.

Today you will take a scenic, high-speed train journey from Hakone to Hiroshima. Although famous for its historical past, Hiroshima is now a modern, thriving, and cosmopolitan city. After checking into your hotel, you’ll have time to appreciate its wide boulevards and laid-back riverside setting.

Spend your afternoon on an insightful Peace Cycling Tour with a Local Guide. You will cycle through the city, beginning at the Peace Memorial Park, dedicated to honoring the victims of the atomic bombing. Your guide will introduce you to significant monuments, including the iconic Atomic Bomb Dome, and share stories of the city's incredible resilience and transformation into a symbol of global peace.

Embark on a meaningful Miyajima Half-Day Trip Historical Walking Tour to the Sacred Island of the Gods. With a local guide, you will take an in-depth look at the famous Itsukushima Shrine with its "floating" torii gate, and the serene Daishoin Temple. The tour provides unique insights into the differences between the Japanese Shinto religion and Buddhism, and concludes with a relaxed local Hiroshima lunch. Following the tour, you will take a train transfer from Hiroshima to Kyoto, the former imperial capital and Japan’s cultural and spiritual heart.

In the late afternoon, experience the traditional world of geisha on the Kyoto Gion Night Walk. As traditional lanterns light up, your guide will lead you through Gion, Kyoto's famous geisha district, uncovering beautifully preserved teahouses and elegant restaurants in the narrow backstreets. You might even catch a glimpse of a geiko or maiko! You’ll then stroll down Hanamikoji Street, lined with traditional wooden buildings, before concluding at Yasaka Shrine (Gion Shrine), an important Shinto site.

Dedicate your day to exploring Kyoto’s magnificent natural and cultural wonders on the Arashiyama Bamboo, Temple, Matcha, Monkeys, & secrets tour. Step into the magical Arashiyama Bamboo Forest, where towering stalks create a serene, otherworldly atmosphere. You'll visit the historic, UNESCO World Heritage Tenryuji Temple with its beautiful zen garden. The journey continues through the vibrant Kimono Forest, across the iconic Togetsu-kyo Bridge, and concludes with a hike up to the Iwatayama Monkey Park for stunning views of Kyoto.
Your incredible journey comes to an end today. After breakfast, you will take a train transfer from Kyoto to Kansai Airport (KIX) for your departure, carrying memories of Japan's majestic highlights.

tourName: Japan and South Korea holiday
generalInfo: Your journey begins in Tokyo, where you'll stay at Henn na Hotel Tokyo Hamamatsucho. Experience a full-day trip to Mount Fuji, Kawaguchi Lake, and Oshino Hakkai, followed by a thrilling Street Kart adventure in Shibuya. Next, travel to Takayama and check in at Residence Hotel Takayama-Ekimae, with a visit to the stunning World Heritage Sites of Shirakawago and Gokayama. Continue to Kyoto, staying at Luck You Kyoto, and enjoy a magical Gion Night Walk and explore Arashiyama’s beautiful bamboo forest and temples. Then, head to Hiroshima for a memorable Peace Cycling Tour with a local guide. Your journey continues in Fukuoka for some relaxation before heading to Busan, South Korea, for a brief stay. Visit Gyeongju next, where you'll enjoy a two-day templestay at Golgulsa Temple. Finally, wrap up your adventure with stops in Jeonju and Seoul, where you’ll take part in a walking tour of the capital.

dayInfo.description: Begin your journey by catching a train to the bustling metropolis of Tokyo, setting the stage for your adventure ahead.

Meet your guide at a convenient Tokyo location and embark on a scenic 2.5-hour bus ride to the iconic Mount Fuji. Capture breathtaking photos at LAWSON Kawaguchiko Station and participate in an authentic Japanese tea ceremony by Lake Kawaguchi. Soar to new heights with the Mt. Kachi Kachi Ropeway, offering stunning views of Mount Fuji and Lake Kawaguchi, before exploring the enchanting village of Oshino Hakkai. As the day concludes, return to Tokyo.

Experience the thrill of driving a custom go-kart through the streets of Tokyo in costume. Conquer the world-famous Shibuya Crossing and explore the vibrant districts of Harajuku and Omotesando. This one-of-a-kind tour promises excitement and memorable photo opportunities.

Catch a train to the charming town of Takayama, where you'll have a free day to explore this scenic destination at your own pace. Discover its traditional wooden buildings, browse quaint shops, and soak in the serene atmosphere that surrounds this beautiful location.

Journey into history with a visit to the Ainokura Gassho Community in Gokayama, a UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its unique thatched-roof houses. Continue to the historic Shirakawa-go village, exploring its timeless architecture and picturesque views.
Travel to Kyoto, where ancient traditions meet modern life.

Immerse yourself in the magical atmosphere of Gion, Kyoto’s famous geisha district. Wander through narrow streets lit by traditional lanterns. Visit Hanamikoji Street and the iconic Yasaka Shrine, soaking in the history and serenity of Kyoto.

Explore the enchanting Arashiyama Bamboo Forest and the exquisite Okochi Sanso Garden. Discover the historic Tenryuji Temple before a scenic walk through the Kimono Forest and crossing the Togetsu-kyo Bridge. End the day with a hike to Iwatayama Monkey Park for stunning views and playful encounters with wild monkeys.
Board a train to Hiroshima and take in the city's contemporary charm and deep historical significance.
Spend a free day exploring Hiroshima at your leisure, discovering its cultural and historical sites.
Continue your journey with a train ride to Fukuoka, a city radiating dynamic energy and culinary delight.
Enjoy a leisurely car ferry ride to Busan, South Korea's vibrant port city, where urban excitement meets a relaxed coastal vibe.
Explore Busan’s beautiful beaches, indulge in local seafood, and stroll through the colorful streets of Gamcheon Culture Village.
Immerse yourself in a serene temple stay experience, engaging in Seonmudo training, meditation, and reflection. Relish in this unique opportunity to embrace the tranquil rhythms of spiritual life.
Immerse yourself in a serene temple stay experience, engaging in Seonmudo training, meditation, and reflection. Relish in this unique opportunity to embrace the tranquil rhythms of spiritual life.
Travel to the charming city of Jeonju, known for its rich history and vibrant culture.
Arrive in Seoul, where tradition and cutting-edge innovation merge. Visit the Jogyesa Temple, wander through the historic Bukchon Hanok Village, and explore the cultural hub of Insadong.
Conclude your memorable journey with a heart full of experiences and a deeper understanding of the wonders of East Asia. Safe travels!

tourName: Japan anime holiday, 7 days
generalInfo:
Experience the essence of Japanese culture through the lens of anime on our exclusive 7-day Japan Anime Tour. Delve into Tokyo's vibrant anime scene as you visit top museums, electrifying shopping districts, and indoor theme parks dedicated to your favourite anime characters.

Join a group of fellow anime enthusiasts and meet experts who will guide you through this immersive journey into the world of anime.

Included in all tours:

An epic Adventure Leader, aka a local legend, to turn your trip into the adventure of a lifetime
All local transport within Japan
Accommodation
Meals provided: There are no meals included on this tour, but your Adventure Leader can recommend some epic spots!
Please note: Accommodation is in 4-8 bedded dorm rooms as a standard on our Japan tours.

Accommodation style:

In true backpacking style, our accommodation is in shared dorm rooms as standard on this tour. But if you’d prefer a little extra comfort and your own space to relax after an action-packed day, room upgrades are available. Please request this on booking.

Included activities:

Visit Tokyo Tower Observatory (Tokyo)
Pass by the stairs at Suga Shrine from the anime Your Name (Tokyo)
Explore Harajuku District and cosplay culture (Tokyo)
Explore Shibuya with stops at Pokémon Center, One Piece Store and Tokyo Anime Center (Tokyo)
Visit DiverCity Tokyo Plaza and see the life-size Unicorn Gundam (Tokyo)
Walk to Aqua City Odaiba and explore the Odaiba Retro Museum (Tokyo)
Visit the Ghibli Giant Clock at Nittele Tower (Tokyo)
Visit Tokiwaso Manga Museum (Tokyo)
Explore Akihabara, Tokyo’s anime and gaming paradise (Tokyo)
Play arcade games with your crew in Tokyo (Tokyo)
Visit Kanda Shrine, beloved by otaku culture (Tokyo)
Themed café chosen by your Adventure Leader (Tokyo)
Karaoke bar (Tokyo)

dayInfo.description: Tokyo: Touch down in Tokyo, Japan’s buzzing capital, and meet your Adventure Leader in the hostel lobby. You’ll get a full trip briefing covering the itinerary, health and safety in Japan, and a chance to meet your new travel crew. Once settled, we’ll head to Tokyo Tower for sweeping views of the city skyline — and don’t miss the quirky anime-themed manhole cover nearby! In the evening, the city is yours to explore. Dive straight into the action at Tokyo Tower RED, a high-tech playground packed with anime collaborations, VR games, and eSports zones. It’s the perfect way to kick off your anime-themed adventure!

Tokyo: This morning, we’ll pass by the famous stairs at Suga Shrine, made iconic by the anime Your Name. Beyond its anime fame, the shrine itself has deep roots in the Edo period, blending centuries of tradition with modern pop culture. Next, we’ll head to Harajuku, Tokyo’s ultimate fashion district. Cosplay shops, colorful snacks, and quirky trends make this one of the city’s liveliest neighborhoods. Just around the corner, you’ll find NHK Hall and Yoyogi Park — hubs for concerts, cosplay meetups, and idol fan gatherings that are a staple of anime culture. Later in the afternoon, it’s time to explore Shibuya, a buzzing district featured in countless anime, including Jujutsu Kaisen. You’ll have free time to visit Parco, the Pokémon Center, the One Piece Mugiwara Store, and the Tokyo Anime Center — all iconic spots no anime fan should miss. In the evening, for those craving extra fun, try Kartoon Karting and zip through Tokyo’s neon streets like a scene straight out of your favourite anime!

Tokyo: Kick off the day at DiverCity Tokyo Plaza to see the life-size Unicorn Gundam in action and explore Gundam Base, a paradise for fans of the iconic mecha series. Next, take a stroll to Aqua City Odaiba and step back in time at the Retro Museum, filled with classic arcades, nostalgic snacks, and a cozy Showa-era atmosphere. The afternoon is yours to enjoy however you like. Why not dive into Joypolis, Tokyo’s famous indoor amusement park packed with VR rides, simulators, and anime collaborations like Attack on Titan? We’ll wrap up the day at the Ghibli Giant Clock at Nittele Tower, a whimsical creation straight from the imagination of Hayao Miyazaki — perfect for some magical photo ops!

Tokyo: Today begins in Ikebukuro, one of Tokyo’s most vibrant anime and shopping hubs. You’ll have free time to explore Sunshine Mall and the surrounding area, packed with highlights for every fan. Step into Namja Town, Bandai Namco’s quirky indoor theme park with retro streets and themed food stalls. Visit Pokémon Center Mega Tokyo, the largest in Japan, and don’t miss Animate Ikebukuro Main Store, a multi-floor haven for manga, figures, and collectibles. If you’re feeling adventurous, opt for a cosplay photo session to capture some epic snaps in true anime style. Later in the afternoon, we’ll head to the Tokiwaso Manga Museum, the birthplace of the modern manga era — an absolute must for anyone who loves Japanese comics.

Tokyo: Today is all yours to explore Tokyo and beyond at your own pace. Whether you’re chasing theme parks, coastal towns, or anime icons, there’s plenty to choose from. Here are some ideas to make the most of your day: Feel the magic at Tokyo Disneyland or DisneySea. Wander Kamakura’s coastal streets, see the Great Buddha, and snap a photo at the famous First Slam Dunk railway crossing. Geek out at the Fujiko F Fujio Museum in Kawasaki. Step into kawaii heaven at Sanrio Puroland. Go all out at Naruto Town in Fuji Q Highland. The choice is yours — whether you’re seeking thrills, culture, or pure anime fun, today is made for your adventure!

Tokyo: This morning, we head to Akihabara, Tokyo’s ultimate paradise for anime and gaming. Explore multi-floor stores, manga shops, and figure collections, then dive into Japan’s famous arcades. From retro classics to the latest games, challenge your travel crew in friendly competitions or join a group activity. Just a short walk away, we’ll visit Kanda Shrine, a traditional Shinto shrine beloved by otaku culture. In the afternoon, the group will regroup at a themed café or fun spot chosen by your Adventure Leader — the perfect chance to swap stories, show off your favorite purchases, and reflect on your adventure. For our last hurrah, we’ll head to a karaoke bar — the ultimate Japanese night out and the perfect way to celebrate the end of your anime journey together.

Tokyo: Today marks the end of your anime adventure. Take the morning to say goodbye to your travel crew and reflect on all the amazing experiences you’ve shared over the past week. Whether you’re heading off to your next destination or making your way home, we hope you’ve had a memorable and fun-filled time in Japan! If you’d like to extend your stay, we can help arrange extra nights for an additional fee — just let us know in advance.

tourName: Japan backpacking holiday, 2 weeks
generalInfo: Embark on an unforgettable Japan adventure, designed for backpackers seeking cultural immersion and thrilling experiences. Explore iconic cities like Tokyo and Kyoto, with visits to historic temples, vibrant markets, and serene gardens. Enjoy traditional Japanese cuisine, soak in rejuvenating hot springs, and stay in unique accommodations. Engage in exciting activities including sumo-wrestling shows and samurai lessons. This tour promises a perfect blend of modern and ancient Japan, offering captivating journeys through scenic landscapes and bustling urban hubs.

dayInfo.description: Tokyo, Japan: Today marks the exciting start of your adventure tour in Japan! At 4 PM, you'll meet with your group for an introductory session led by your Adventure Leader. During this meeting, you'll receive detailed information about what the upcoming two weeks will bring, along with essential tips on embracing Japanese culture and ensuring your safety throughout the tour. Once the briefing concludes, you'll dive into your first unforgettable experience—participating in a sushi-making class. In this hands-on activity, you'll learn to craft some of Japan's classic dishes and then enjoy the fruits of your labor as you dine on your homemade sushi for dinner. As the evening unfolds, prepare to be amazed by panoramic views of the city's skyline as you visit the top of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. To cap off your first day, you have the option to join your group at a local bar, where you can unwind, socialize, and perhaps even forge lasting friendships with your fellow travelers, who share your adventurous spirit.

Tokyo, Japan: We'll kick off the day by exploring the Tsukiji Outer Market, a landmark district famous for its superb sushi offerings due to its access to freshly delivered fish. Meander through the vibrant stalls and enjoy some delicious sashimi as you go! Our next stop is Asakusa, where we'll explore the iconic Sensoji Temple. This historic Buddhist temple is alive with activity and home to the traditional Nakamise-dori street. Still have room for more? Sample some local snacks! You'll then have free time to delve into Asakusa at your leisure: There’s an extraordinary opportunity to take part in a Sumo experience, where you’ll meet former Sumo wrestlers and savor a traditional chanko nabe lunch. Alternatively, you might want to take in the stunning vistas of Tokyo from the Sky Tree tower. Or treat yourself to a different perspective of the city with a Sumida River cruise. A peek into Japanese history awaits at the Samurai Museum. Later, we regroup and travel to Akihabara, Japan’s 'Electric Town'. Known for its dazzling stores and arcades, it's an anime and manga lover's dream. Capture the essence of Akihabara with a visit to one of its unique maid cafés. The evening is yours to explore Tokyo to your heart’s content. Shopping enthusiasts can wander through Ginza's boutiques and luxury goods. Seek some action with a visit to a traditional Japanese batting cage or unwind by experiencing a Japanese bathhouse.

Tokyo, Japan: Begin your morning with a trip to one of the city's most renowned landmarks, the Meiji Shrine. Dedicated to Emperor Meiji, who played a pivotal role in Japan's industrial advancement, and his wife Empress Shoken, this shrine is a must-visit. Next, journey to Harajuku, Tokyo's top fashion district, where you'll encounter an eclectic mix of styles, including punk, goth, and vibrant technicolor hair. Spend some time exploring the bustling streets, dotted with vintage shops like Chicago and acclaimed restaurants. Continue to Shibuya, home to the world's busiest pedestrian crossing. This iconic sight is a must-see, as millions traverse it daily. In the afternoon, enjoy exploring Tokyo at your own leisure. For an exhilarating experience, try Kartoon Karting through the streets. Alternatively, immerse yourself in the digital-meets-natural art installations at teamLab Planets. For a more relaxed pace, visit the tranquil gardens of the Imperial Palace, the Japanese Emperor's residence.

Tokyo, Japan: Today, we rise early for an exhilarating day trip to Fujikawaguchiko, bringing us close to the awe-inspiring Mount Fuji. Immerse yourself in this remarkable region by visiting: - Arakurayama Sangen Park, a tranquil and picturesque shrine situated at the base of Fuji. - A brief hike to Tenku no Torii (the Torii Gate by the Sky), where on clear days, you'll capture stunning views of Fuji from this prime photographic location. - A hike to Haha no Shirataki (Mother White’s Waterfall), offering more chances to admire Fuji while exploring this delightful natural site. As night falls, we'll return to Tokyo for our final evening. You have the option to unwind with an early night or join your group for a few farewell drinks before departure.

Tokyo - Kamakura, Japan: Today, you'll transition from the vibrant city streets to the serene beaches of Kamakura. A morning train ride will bring you to your destination around midday. After a quick lunch, you'll immerse yourself in the unique cultural experience of a calligraphy class held inside a local temple. The afternoon is at your leisure to discover Kamakura's charming attractions. You can visit the Kotoku-in Temple to see the famed Great Buddha Statue, explore the enchanting bamboo forest at Hokokuji Temple, or enjoy a relaxing time at the picturesque beaches, perfect for witnessing a beautiful ocean sunset.

Kamakura - Hakone, Japan: Our day starts with departing from Kamakura and venturing into the picturesque region of Hakone, arriving around midday. We'll begin with a hike along the historical Old Hakaido route, where we'll pause for lunch near Moto-Hakone. Post-lunch, we'll embark on a unique sightseeing cruise on a pirate ship, crossing the serene Lake Ashi. If the skies are clear, expect breathtaking views of Mount Fuji. Following this, our journey takes us on the Hakone ropeway to Owakudani, a dynamic volcanic zone known for its black eggs, a local treat rumored to extend your life by seven years. The evening promises relaxation in a traditional Japanese onsen, soaking in sulfuric waters. Afterward, don a yukata and delve into the world of Japanese rice wine, with a sake tasting session to enhance your knowledge and enjoyment.

Hakone - Kyoto, Japan: Today's adventure starts with a journey to Kyoto, with a mid-morning stopover in Odawara. You'll have a couple of hours to explore Odawara at your leisure before boarding the bullet train to continue on to Kyoto. Upon arrival, your Adventure Leader will guide you on a brief tour along the scenic Kamo River, helping you get oriented with the city. The rest of the afternoon is free for you to embark on your own exploration. Consider visiting the historic Nishihonganjj temple, renowned for its striking architecture, or wander through the serene Shosei-en Gardens, celebrated for their seasonal blossoms. Alternatively, explore Sanjusangendo temple, famous for its hall that houses 1,001 statues of Kannon, the Buddhist goddess of mercy. For something different, head to the Mandarake store, which boasts a collection of rare manga and vintage toys. In the evening, if you enjoy singing, you might want to join your group for a fun karaoke night.

Kyoto, Japan: You'll begin your day with a visit to Higashi Hongan-ji Temple, renowned as one of the world's largest wooden structures. This serene spot is perfect for exploration, and we'll arrive before the crowds set in. Next, we'll visit the iconic Fushimi Inari Shrine, known for its thousands of vibrant red torii gates. You can choose to hike to the top for stunning views of Kyoto or return to the city for some delicious street food. In the early afternoon, we'll head to the Kiyomizu-dera Temple, a spectacular UNESCO World Heritage site. Afterwards, your Adventure Leader will guide you through the historic Gion district before you spend your evening as you wish. Options include: wandering through the charming Pontocho Alley, experiencing a live performance at Gion Corner, or visiting Yasaka Shrine, beautifully lit at night.

Kyoto, Japan: This morning, we'll journey to the picturesque city of Nara via train for a half-day excursion. During our visit, we'll marvel at the magnificent Todaiji Temple, which houses one of the world's largest bronze Buddha statues. Additionally, we'll wander through Nara Park, where the friendly local deer may just become your new companions. You'll have an opportunity to enjoy lunch in Nara before returning to Kyoto. Upon our return, the afternoon is yours to enjoy: - Participate in a traditional tea ceremony hosted by a genuine geisha. - Discover the enchanting Arashiyama bamboo forest, the serene Tenryu-ji temple and gardens, and visit the lively monkey park. - Experience a taste of Japanese geisha culture by renting a kimono. - Explore the Pokémon Center for a delightful experience tailored to enthusiasts. - Immerse yourself in Japanese pop culture with a visit to the Manga Museum.

Kyoto - Hiroshima, Japan: In the morning, we're hopping on bikes for a half-day city cycle tour. Our first stop is a Zen temple, where you'll have the opportunity to relax and find inner peace through a meditation session with a Buddhist monk, followed by experiencing a traditional tea ceremony. Afterward, we'll pause for lunch before visiting Kyoto's iconic Golden Pavilion at Kinkaku-ji. We'll cycle past the Imperial Palace on our way to our next destination. This afternoon, we'll take the bullet train to Hiroshima, arriving just in time for dinner. You can choose to join the group for an interactive dining experience at Okonomiyaki Village, where the chef will cook your meal right before your eyes!

Hiroshima, Japan: This morning, we'll begin our journey by visiting the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum and the Atomic Bomb Dome, immersing ourselves in a pivotal aspect of Japanese history. Afterwards, we'll take a ferry to Miyajima Island, renowned for its scenic beauty. Here, you can explore the famous Itsukushima Shrine, where, during low tide, walking beneath the grand torii gate is possible. After enjoying lunch, we’ll ascend the Miyajima ropeway to capture breathtaking views of the island from the mountain. We'll return to Hiroshima in the evening, offering you the freedom to explore the city at your own pace.

Hiroshima - Osaka, Japan: We’re catching an early train to reach our final stop – Osaka. Upon arrival, your Adventure Leader will guide you on a brief tour of the city, concluding at the lively Shinsaibashi street, an ideal place to explore and grab lunch! Afterward, enjoy free time to discover Osaka at your leisure. Potential activities include visiting the historic Osaka Castle for breathtaking city views, indulging in shopping along Umeda Street, or delving into Japan’s history at the National Museum. In the evening, regroup with your fellow travelers for a farewell dinner in Shinsekai, where you can capture a photo with the iconic Tsutenkaku Tower. If you're up for a little more fun, end the night with a final drink in Shinsaibashi with your group.

Osaka, Japan: Today is the final day of your budget-friendly journey through Japan. Whether you're off to a new adventure or heading back home, we trust you had a memorable experience exploring Japan.

tourName: Japan backpacking tour
placesVisited: Tokyo, Kamakura, Hakone, Kyoto, Arashiyama, Hiroshima, Miyajima Island, Osaka, Japan Rail Pass included, Activities include: sushi lesson, sake tasting, sightseeing cruise, onsen visit, karaoke
generalInfo:
Japan has a reputation for being pricey, but you can keep costs down by staying in hostels (like a true backpacker) in shared rooms, and even one night in a capsule hotel. Your tour leader knows some great authentic, but cheap restaurants – Osaka is brilliant for street food and you’ll get a sushi lesson in Tokyo. You’ll be given a Japan Rail Pass to get around without spending a fortune, and you can ride the famous bullet train.

You need to devote a lot of time to Tokyo, which is why this tour takes four days to get to know the capital – one minute you’ll be taking a swing at a batting cage, the next relaxing in a local bathhouse or going to see a robot show. By doing local activities, there no queues or big crowds involved – except, of course, when you visit Shibuya Crossing, the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.

A bullet train to Kyoto whizzes you back in time in Japan’s elegant, historic city. Just as it’s essential to spend lots of time in Tokyo, you need to give Kyoto a few day’s attention, too. See geisha performances, witness a tea ceremony and cycle around the city to Zen temples, Kinkaku-ji, and the Imperial Palace. Finally you’ll visit Hiroshima, with its moving Peace Memorial Park, before filling your stomach in Osaka – Japan's greediest city and returning to Tokyo on the bullet train again.

dayInfo.description: Tokyo- Your tour begins at 10am! Join the group for an orientation followed by a visit to the Senso- Ji temple in the Asakusa district. Enjoy a sashimi lunch in Tokyo’s famous Tsukiji Outer Market and then take in cityscape views from the top of the Metropolitan Government building. There is the option to try your hand at baseball, visit a Japanese bathhouse or shop around Asakusa later on that day.

Tokyo- Get a culinary lesson from a skilled sushi chef before visiting the ‘electric town’ of Akihabara. Enjoy some free time in the town and maybe visit one of the gimmicky maid cafés. If you’d like to bring an old-time favourite video game to life, you can choose to take part in a MariCar! experience. Hit the night life at the Golden Gai club post-drive!

Tokyo - In the morning you’ll visit the impressive Tokyo Imperial Palace it’s stunning gardens. Spend some time in the wacky fashion district of Harajuku and in the afternoon head to Shibuya to visit the Meiji Shrine. You’ll also get to walk Shibuya’s busiest pedestrian crossing to visit the iconic Hachiko statue. Recharge with a coffee break at a cat café before getting ready for Roppongi’s nightlife!

Tokyo- Today’s a culture experience with a scheduled visit to Tokyo’s fascinating Edo-Tokyo history museum in Ryogoku. You’ll have the option to experience ‘a day in the life’ of a sumo wrestler followed by a visit to the Sumo Museum to find out about the traditional Japanese sport. The afternoon offers a chance to learn the ancient art of samurai with a live sword demonstration, and you’ll even try on a samurai outfit and have a go yourself! A Robot Show experience is on offer for some evening

Kamakura - After brunch you’ll jump on a train to the historical town Kamakura. The hostel you’ll be staying at is a stone’s throw from the beach where you can relax or if feeling adventurous, try your hand at surfing! Witness all historical aspects of this town including ancient shrines and the Kotoku-in temple hike where you’ll get to stand in awe of the Great Buddha statue. For a real treat you’ll hop over to the small offshore island of Enoshima to visit little temples and enjoy the sunset from a selection of beachside bars.
Hakone - Travel up the Hakone Ropeway for sensational views of Mount Fiji. Try out a local cuisine - black eggs

Kyoto - Bullet train over to Kyoto, covering 440 km in 2 hours. Wander the hillside streets to the Fushimi Inari Shrine, renowned for it’s multiple torii gates leading into the wooded forest of the sacred Mount Inari. The evening offers a beautiful geisha performance including a tea ceremony, puppet show and traditional music. Meander through the Pontocho alley, lit up with little lanterns and plenty of wood-panelled restaurants where you can sip sake and watch the geisha’s go by.

Arashiyama, Kyoto - Take a trip down the Hozugawa River in a traditional wooden raft. Driven by guides, you’ll cruise through the breath-taking Arashiyama Hills, navigating rocky ravines and rushing rapids. Trek up the mountain to enjoy panoramic views of picture-perfect Kyoto and meet the local primate residents. Enjoy the Tenryu-Ji Temple and ancient 14th century gardens before a final hike though the mystical Bamboo forest. Tonight, it’s Karaoke!

Kyoto - Today you have the opportunity to independently enjoy Kyoto and its surrounding areas. We suggest temple hopping along the Philosopher’s path, or you could check out the International Manga Museum. The Fushimi Inari Shrine area offers a breath-taking hiking trail through a corridor made up of thousands of bright red Japanese gates. In the evening, enjoy a few sake’s with your new friends.

Kyoto/Hiroshima - Cycle to a Zen temple to take part in a spiritual mediation session led by a Buddhist monk. You’ll go to the iconic Golden Pavilion at Kinkaku- Ji and circle the mirror pond to be mesmerised by its golden reflection. In the afternoon, you can cycle around the Imperial palace, before jumping on another bullet train bound for Hiroshima!

Hiroshima - This modern city on Japan’s Honshu Island was largely destroyed by the famous atomic bomb during World War II. The Peace Memorial Park commemorates the event that occurred in 1945 and explains how Hiroshima is now a world leader in striving for a peaceful and nuclear-free world. Take a train and short ferry trip to the Itsukushima shrine on Miyajima Island. Temple buildings were built on stilts to avoid upsetting the gods, and there is an enormous torii gate just offshore which can be reached at low tide. Enjoy a relaxing evening digesting what you’ve learned today

Osaka - You’ll head off on another bullet train to Osaka, just in time for a traditional Japanese lunch of Ramen, sushi or yakitori in the foody district of Shinsaibashi. The famous Osaka castle is an iconic landmarks that played a major part in Japan’s reunification during the 16th century. Stroll around the moat and don’t get lost exploring the 9-level dungeon! During your free afternoon, explore Shinsaibashi before your final night out on the town. Tonight you’ll sleep in a unique ‘capsule hotel’ which is an experience in itself!
Osaka back to Tokyo -enjoy a final brunch before catching your bullet train back to Tokyo for a 4.30pm arrival. Happy travelling if you’re continuing to explore Japan and beyond!

tourName: Japan cities and beach tour
generalInfo:
Tokyo - Hakone/Mount Fuji - Kyoto - Okinawa - Tokyo

Japan is the ultimate bucket list destination: Think incredibly cities, dynamic and dramatic landscapes, the epicentre of traditional culture and ever changing modernity, blissful island beaches, brilliant food... all in one roundtrip carefully curated by our dedicated team of Japan specific specialists.

Your tour begins in Tokyo, a mesmerising metropolis of temples, markets, modernity and technology. Head straight into the fray or sit back and people watch with a matcha... the choice is yours.

From cityscape to unparalleled natural landscapes: head to the foot of Fuji via rail, boat over Ashino-ko Lake, or hike. However you visit, this is a view you are unlikely to forget.

Next stop, famous and picturesque Kyoto, host of tea ceremonies, artistry, and a sense of zen which pervades the town. We recommend taking a bike to explore the sites and sights.

Today you will take a flight to the island of Okinawa archipelago where you will enjoy some blissful down time on white sand beaches framed by turquoise waves. We can arrange snorkelling tours here as well as ample time to enjoy the peace and freedom on your own.

Give us a call to tailor this plan to your tastes and speak to a friendly Japan specialist today.

dayInfo.description: LET'S GO TOKYO: One of the world’s truly great cities, Tokyo is a thrilling mix of the past and future, complete with incredible cuisine, neon-lit nightlife and unique pop-culture. After being picked up from the airport and transferred to your hotel near the heart of the city, you’ll have plenty of time to visit the contrasting areas which make up this unique metropolis. You’ll also take an evening tour of Shibuya with a guide popping into a few well-chosen eateries where you can have drinks and try out some delicious bar food. At the end of the tour, you’ll be well prepped to explore the dazzling streets of Tokyo all by yourself, like a true local.

AT THE FOOT OF FUJI: Today you will make your own way to the train station to get your first taste of train travel in Japan en route to Hakone, the gateway to Mount Fuji. For the next couple of days you’ll stay in Hakone, located near the foot of the mountain and beside Ashino-ko Lake, providing a spectacular setting from which to take in the majesty of Fuji. The town is understandably popular and provides multiple tourist attractions and facilities, so we’ll provide a pass so that you can experience them at your own pace. You’ll have plenty of options – ride the railway, take a boat trip on the lake, visit the impressive Hakone Shrine or some of the many museums – it totally up to you! There are also some great hiking trails if you feel like escaping the crowds. After a full day of exploring you can relax in one of the town’s many Onsen, and grab yourself some tasty Japanese cuisine at one of the many excellent restaurants.

UNCOVER THE HEART OF KYOTO: Next up you will make your way to the train station and head to pretty Kyoto. When you think of Japan, you might imagine ancient temples, perfectly manicured zen gardens and time honoured tea ceremonies. Well, that’s Kyoto in a nutshell! During this trip you’ll spend 2 nights in this pretty city and hop aboard a bike to discover the city’s hidden backstreets. You can expect to whizz past willow lined rivers, along narrow streets and alongside traditional merchant houses.

BLISSFUL BAYS OF OKINAWA: Today you’ll be collected from your hotel in Kyoto and taken to the airport to catch a flight to Okinawa, a subtropical archipelago that couldn’t differ more to the mainland Japan. Think white sandy beaches, warm turquoise ocean and over 150 islands dotted around the East China sea. With a distinctive islandic culture and a strong American influence, Okinawa has got its own flavour. After all, neon lights and swaying palm trees go very well together. Who knew! You’ll land in Naha airport and get transferred to your beachside hotel, about an hour away. Here you’ll spend three blissful nights (let us know if you fancy to have more downtime here!), falling asleep to the sound of crashing ocean waves. The hotel has an excellent restaurant and a huge swimming pool. And there are beaches and beautiful parks to keep you entertained too. While you are in Okinawa we will arrange for you to explore the amazing underwater world on a snorkelling tour. You will be collected from your hotel and taken to board the boat, where your knowledgeable local guide awaits. They will take you and other travellers to some pretty spectacular snorkelling locations where you can observe coral reefs and their inhabitants. The variety of the marine life here is exceptional! After the tour you’ll be transferred back to your hotel. We haven’t planned anything else for your time in Okinawa so you could enjoy your free time and explore the island at your own pace.

NEON NIGHT IN TOKYO: At the end of your stay in Okinawa, you will be picked up from your hotel and transferred back to Naha airport on time for your flight back to Tokyo, for another night in the neon city. As your Japanese adventure comes to an end you will spend one more night in this bustling city, take a final walk past the towering skyscrapers and tuck into some tasty sushi. The following morning you will be collected and taken to the airport for your international flight home. Before heading through customs and security, remember to post your pocket wifi unit back through the airport post office.

tourName: Japan classic tour by rail
generalInfo:
Begin your journey arriving in to the excitement of Tokyo. You have your first day at leisure to relax after your long-haul flights and perhaps explore the imperial gardens. On your first full day a specialist local guide will be at hand to help you get your bearings in the city with a fully flexible orientation day. This is your opportunity to ask any questions you may have or get help with you train tickets for instance, to ensure you can enjoy Japan with confidence. This afternoon you will explore some of Tokyo's highlights as well as the culinary delicacies of Ebisu. Now that you're confident navigating in Japan, you have another day at leisure to yourselves. you may like to explore Tokyo further, or take the train out to the seaside town of Kamakura.

Delve in to the beautifully preserved past of Japan today as you head to Tsumago by bullet train. You'll spend the afternoon trekking through peaceful countryside and rice paddies, passing many temples along the historic Nakasendo 'highway', which once connected Kyoto and Edo. Tonight you will enjoy the traditional hospitality of a local Ryokan.

Your next two days are spent in peaceful reflection in Hiroshima. Stroll down tree lined avenues, from the Peace Park to the Memorial Museum. Over on Miyajima island, explore shrines and temples and admire the unique 'floating' red torii gate.

Taking the bullet train east, you will arrive at Kyoto in time for an afternoon tour of the beautiful gardens and temples to be found here, before heading over to the iconic Geisha quarter of Gion. The next day is dedicated to culture, as you spend the morning with the Womens Association, learning about their traditions, from Origami, to tea ceremonies and kimono. After lunch, explore the highlights of Kyoto, from shrines to markets and the impressive Nijo Castle, at your own leisure.

Take a local train today out to Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine, home to hundreds of red torii gates and one of the most iconic images of Japan. From here you can explore the surrounding forest before continuing on to one of the former capital cities, Nara, where you can visit daibutsu Buddha and even have the chance to feed the wild deer by hand.

Your next two days are dedicated to discovering Hakone national park, at the base of Mt Fuji. With your 'Hakone Free Pass' you have the freedom to explore by bus, train or cable car. You may like to visit some of the many beautiful view points, the Chokokunomori sculpture museum, view Mt Fuji from a replica pirate ship, or simply relax in a traditional hot spring.

Return to Tokyo and take advantage of one more night in this unique city before your departure home tomorrow.

dayInfo.description: Today you begin your journey by boarding your international outbound flight to Tokyo.

After passing through customs and luggage collection, you're met by an airport guide who will give you your trip documents and direct you to the shared shuttle service which takes you to your hotel. After checking in, spend the rest of the day at leisure, resting and relaxing after your flight. If you do feel like starting exploring, you may wish to walk around the Imperial Gardens.

Your guide will meet you today in the hotel lobby to run through your trip and offer any local advice to you so you can enjoy the country with confidence. In the first section the guide will explain your itinerary in more detail and answer any questions you might have. They can also assist with validating your Japan rail pass. This can take up to two hours so afterwards head out with your guide to see some of the highlights of the city. In the evening, head out with a guide to sample some of the local Tokyo cuisine in the vibrant district of Ebisu.

A day at leisure. We suggest getting out of the city and catching the train (the journey lasts an hour and a quarter one way) to the seaside town of Kamakura, southwest of Tokyo. In this 800-year-old town you can see the Great Buddha of Kotokuin, and a number of scenic temples and shrines. Upon returning to Tokyo, head to one of our recommended restaurants for an evening meal.

Travel by bullet train and local trains to Tsumago, a quiet post town in the Kiso Valley. This afternoon, walk along the scenic Nakasendo Highway, which once connected Kyoto and Edo (Tokyo) in the 1800s. It was an important route used by samurai and traders. Temples line the route and you'll pass through paddy fields and other peaceful countryside. This evening, enjoy your first evening meal at a traditional inn or 'ryokan'.

Take the train to Hiroshima. This is quite a long journey of five hours and involves changing at Nagoya, then whizzing the rest of the way by bullet train. After checking into your hotel, head to the Peace Park. Despite it being a quite sobering experience, the Japanese have made it an extremely interesting place. Walk along the city's tree-lined avenues and visit the Memorial Museum.

A day at leisure to explore Hiroshima and its surroundings at your own pace. We suggest taking the 20 minute ferry crossing to nearby Miyajima Island to see its 'floating' red torii gate. It stands out in the bay and is completely surrounded by water at high tide, giving the impression that it floats. Miyajima Island itself is full of interesting shrines and temples. During October and November its Japanese Maples turn a rich dark red.

Take the bullet train east to Kyoto, a journey of around two hours. In the afternoon, head out on a tour with one of our local guides who can help you make the most out of your time in this multi-faceted city. You could stroll around the Ryoanji gardens and Silver pavillion temple or head to the geisha quarter.

In the morning, we can arrange for you to take part in a private cultural activity at Kyoto's Women's Association. With the help of experienced English-speaking practitioners, you can have an introduction to Japanese culture by trying origami, a tea ceremony and wearing a traditional Japanese kimono. After the class, spend the afternoon at leisure in Kyoto. Navigate your way around the city seeing the many gardens, shrines and shops of this unique city. Highlights include the Golden Pavilion, the food markets selling tasty Japanese delicacies, and the impressive Nijo castle.

Take a local train to visit Fushimi Inari Taisha shrine, a quick five minute train journey from Kyoto. The shrine is home to hundreds of red torii gates that spill out over the hillside. It's also worth taking a walk through the forest there. Continue your journey on to Nara, one of the former capitals of Japan, to feed the wild deer and see the 'daibutsu', a giant Buddha housed inside a wooden building.

Take the bullet train to Hakone, a journey of around three and a half hours. Check in to your accommodation and either head to a hot spring to relax for the rest of the day, or use our folders to navigate your way around the National Park. You can use your Hakone free pass to reach several great viewing areas over the park's mountains and lakes.

A day at leisure to further explore Hakone National Park under your own steam. Your included Hakone Free Pass allows you to use the buses, trains and cable cars. Cross Lake Ashinoko on a replica pirate ship or head to a viewing spot for a glimpse of Mount Fuji. We also recommend visiting the excellent open air sculpture museum in Chokokunomori.

After a leisurely morning return to Tokyo (a one and a quarter hour train journey) for a final night in the capital. We suggest using your last few hours in the city to explore a new corner of it. Visit the Imperial Palace Gardens, the man-made island of Odaiba, trendy Shinjuku or the peaceful landscaped Hamarikyu Gardens.
You will be picked up and taken to the airport for your return flights home. Your return flight will arrive the same day.

tourName: Japan culture tour, Shoguns & Samurai
placesVisited: Tokyo, Senso-ji Buddhist temple, Obuse, Yudanaka Onsen, Snow monkeys, Nakasendo Trail, Narai, Tsumago, Magome, Takayama, Kyoto, Nara, Mount Koya
generalInfo:
A two week long, small group tour around Japan’s cultural highlights with our expert and highly experienced local guide. This unique country’s culture and history are so rich, that even a two week long Japan culture tour will still only feel like an introduction, but this itinerary will immerse you deeply and quickly. Every day is different, with the likes of Imperial Kyoto and Nara one day or the ancient Nakasendo Trail, where you can follow in the footsteps of feudal warlords through the mountains, on another. The Trail is 500km long, but we will take on the Kiso Valley section visiting the traditional ‘post towns’ of Magome and Tsumago further over the Magome Pass.

Hot springs and bathing are at the core of Japanese culture, and there are plenty of opportunities to soak on this tour, such as in the ancient city of Takayama in the Hida region, with the backdrop of mountains and ancient wooden houses. Even the monkeys bathe in Japan, as you will see from our visit to the famous snow monkeys of Yudanaka, which take to the hot springs here when mountain temperatures drop.

Kyoto holds the cultural crown of Japan with fourteen UNESCO World Heritage sites. So we spend three days here, allowing plenty of time to visit its ancient temples such as the Golden Pavilion of Kinkakuji, palaces, the historic district of Gion with its omnipresent teahouses and shrines. Also a contemporary metropolis, Kyoto is definitely cultural chic.

Starting and ending in Tokyo, visiting its iconic sites and highlights, one of the high points of this Japan culture tour is on our last night before returning to Tokyo, and something that is in total contrast to its big city lights: Staying overnight at the Buddhist Temple at Mount Koya, where the chanting, serenity and indeed cuisine of the place is unforgettable.

Other accommodation on this trip includes traditional ryokan or minshuku inns, and smaller hotels in the cities. Travelling in a group that is no bigger than thirteen people, you are able to savour each cultural experience, with the help of your English-speaking Japanese tour leader, in the best way possible.

dayInfo.description: The tour starts in Tokyo. Meet your guide and other group members at the tour hotel in central Tokyo. Start exploring the wonder that is Tokyo.

On our second day in Tokyo, we visit Asakusa, famous for the magnificent Senso-ji Buddhist temple, as well as the old residential, or shitamachi, area of Yanaka, After all that walking, end the day on a Sumida River trip to the Hamarikyu gardens.

Today we travel to Obuse to experience two contrasting aspects of Japanese culture: wood block printing, at the dedicated museum, and also a sake brewery at Masuichi-Ichimura. From here we visit one of Japan’s most quirky natural sites, the hot springs at Yudanaka Onsen, famous for the ‘snow monkeys’ that come down from the cool heights to bathe in the warm water. Tonight we stay in a, traditional inn known as a ryokan.

The Nakasendo Trail is an ancient byway that was used by feudal lords to travel between Kyoto and Edo, which is today’s Tokyo. Along the way, there were traditional post towns where travellers stopped for rest and food. Today we visit Narai, one of the remaining post towns, and still retaining its traditional feel. The Trail is a famous walking trail now, and the accommodations along the way are traditional ryokan inns, or smaller minshuku inns, where we will spend the night.

After enjoying some more time on the iconic Nakasendo Trail, including another couple of post towns - Tsumago which is home to a charming Japanese folk museum, and Magome, where we will spend the night in a traditional family run inn, or minshuku. The beautifully-preserved architecture of this village is utterly enchanting.

Today we head to Takayama in the mountainous Hida region, famous for its beef production, which is a must on the menus during our stay here. With a beautifully conserved old town, known as San-machi, wandering around the ancient houses, artisans’ workshops and narrow streets really does take you back in time.

Take the train to Kyoto with two days ahead to explore this cultural gem of a city, with imperial palaces, 14 UNESCO sites such as the Golden Pavilion of Kinkakuji. As well as the historic district of Gion with tea houses tucked into ancient wooden houses, and geishas still going about their duties, serenely and secretly.

Today we head to the stunning, ancient city of Nara, which was the capital city in the 8th century and saw seven emperors rule from here. And so much of it preserved, with Japan’s highest number of buildings designated National Treasures in one city. Hardly surprising, as it was home to seven consecutive emperors, and also a religious transition from Shintoism to Buddhism. Consequently, religious sites here are a must, such as the Todai-ji temple, the Museum of Buddhist Art as well as the largest Buddha statue in Japan.

From cultural highlights to natural ones, we take the superb scenic rail route up to Mount Koya, where no fewer than a hundred Buddhist temples are located. You won’t get to see them all, but you will get to stay in a Buddhist temple’s accommodation tonight, with superb food prepared by the monks. Indeed, Mount Koya is the burial place of Kobo Daishi, the founder of the Shingon Buddhist movement, so it is considered a very holy place.
Take the bullet train back to Tokyo.
Our tour finishes today. Do please ask our tour leader’s advice if you are extending your trip, or require information on travelling to the airport.

tourName: Japan discovery tour, 14 days
generalInfo:
Japan has an air of oriental mystery about it and this discovery tour aims to unveil its wonders over the course of 14 unforgettable days.

This tour takes you from the ultra-modern buzz of Tokyo to the tranquil mountains of Hakone National Park and Takayama. Experience an authentic Japanese ryokan, the world famous bullet train, and a Samurai House. You will also have the opportunity to visit the fascinating but harrowing city of Hiroshima and its mix of beautiful heritage sites and peace memorial museum.

A guide will accompany you to the main heritage sites and you'll travel the length of Japan on its ultra-efficient trainline - a memorable and eco-friendly way to travel.

We pride ourselves on our truly tailor-made trips and we can help organise additional tours or tweak the itinerary if there is anything else you would like to include. Breakfast is included throughout, along with some dinners. Lunches are at your own account. If you need flights please let us know and we would be happy to help. For the full itinerary please contact us.

Your holiday Includes: tours as specified; accommodation; train tickets; services of an English speaking guide; a welcome pack on arrival; 14 day rail pass; assistance from our Japan local ground operator.

Your holiday excludes: international flights & taxes; Visa & any fees; meals other than those specified; travel insurance; items of a personal nature.

dayInfo.description: Arrive in Japan’s buzzing capital, Tokyo, where you will be met and transferred in a shared shuttle to your hotel. At your hotel you will be given an IC (transport) card with money already loaded on it to help you get out and explore the city.

Enjoy a full day tour of Tokyo. Take in the city’s highlights including Kokyo Gaien, the plaza gardens outside the Imperial Palace. Immerse yourself in Tokyo’s past at the Meiji Shrine before walking back through the lush grounds. Stroll through the ulta-hip district of Harakuju where Tokyo’s street style is displayed in all its glory. Turn down Omotesando to a tree-lined building flanked by modern buildings housing top fashion brands and finish your day with an incredible panorama of the city at the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. If the weather is clear you can spot Mount Fuji in the distance. (B)

A whole day to explore. Make use of your travel card and head to the Tsukji Fish Market or explore the city's world-class museums and art galleries. Speak to us if you’d like to arrange a day trip to Kamakura or Nikko to see ancient temples, a giant Bronze Buddha and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Wake early and catch a train to Hakone Nationak Park – the gateway to Mt. Fuji. This small town is loved for its natural hot springs and natural beauty. From here you can use your transport pass to explore the many sights of the park. Ride the ropeway up to Mt Owakudani as it soars over sulphurous fumes and volcanic rivers. Cruise on a replica pirate ship across Ashinoko Lake, ride the Hakone switchback train and keep your eyes peeled for Mt Fuji. When you return, you’ll check into your ryokan, a traditional Japanese Inn and feel as if you’ve been transported to the Edo Period. Sliding doors, rice paper screen and tatami mats make for the ultimate onsen experience complete with opulent multi-course meal.

Take a final soak in the onsen before boarding the famous bullet train to Takayama. Enjoy one of the most scenic routes in Japan on the Limited Express Hida Wideview as you wind your way through mountains and gorges. In Takayama you’ll find a beautifully preserved old-town cut off from the rest of Japan and now with its own distinctive culture.

This morning you can explore the riverside markets famous for their locally grown produce. Wander through the old town to Takayam Jinya – the last remaining government building from Samurai and Shogun times. Next stop is a sake brewery for which the town – and country- are famous. Sample Japan’s iconic drink before enjoying a leisurely afternoon. Ask us for suggestions what to do this afternoon!

Back on the train this morning for a short yet stunning ride to Toyama and finishing at Kanazawa Station. Have a fascinating tour of Terashima Kurando House – a samurai house complete with garden and artworks. Next is Kenrokuen, one of Japan’s top gardens. Finally enjoy a museum stop to learn about the man who introduced Zen Buddhism to the west. Put your knowledge into practice as you relax by the water mirror garden.
Spend the day at leisure exploring

Rise early this morning for your train journey to Hiroshima. The journey takes around 5 hours and you will travel through fascinating scenery. On arrival your guide will take you to the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park, located in the centre of the city. The A-Bomb Dome was one of the few buildings to remain standing and is now the Hiroshima Peace Memorial. Get a birds eye view from the Orizuru Tower.

Nothing planned for today - why not visit the Island of Miyajima. Less than an hour from Hiroshima, its most famous sight is the floating torii gate which at high tide gives the impression of floating on the water, There is a cable car to the top of Mount Misen with superb views and many small shrines and temples to visit.
Travel by train to Kyoto and on arrival, the day is yours to relax and explore.

Start your full day tour of Kyoto at two iconic UNESCO World Heritage Sites - Ginkakuji and Kiyomizudera. Begin with Ginkakuji, also known as the Silver Pavilion, a Zen temple with a beautiful moss garden and a unique dry sand garden. Walk on the Philosopher’s Path, a pleasant stone path through the northern part of Kyoto's Higashiyama district, which follows a canal lined by hundreds of cherry trees. Have lunch by the Yasaka Shrine and partake in a Japanese Tea Ceremony in a traditional tea house. Explore Ninenzaka to discover what Kyoto looked like in the past and visit Kodajji Temple – lavish buildings surrounded by Zen gardens. Finish with a panoramic view of the city.

Take a bento class this morning to learn to cook sushi, tempura and mis soup among other dishes. Discover the cultural background of ‘bento’ and even better, once cooking is finished, sit down and feast on the lunch you have created. The afternoon is at leisure.
Take the bullet train back to Tokyo and travel to the airport to catch your departure flight home.

tourName: Japan family 12 day tour
generalInfo:
Impress your family with our Japan adventure tour; taking you to Tokyo, Hakone, Kyoto, Hiroshima and Osaka. Experience magnificent views of Mt. Fuji, unearth the history of Hiroshima, learn how to make sushi and watch traditional Japanese performances by geishas, comedians and dancers. To give you and your family the best travel experience, we made sure there is something for everyone.

Included in this tour:

An epic Adventure Leader, aka a local legend, to turn your trip into the adventure of a lifetime
All local transport within Japan, plus a JR pass.
Accommodation (including hotels and guesthouse stay)
Meals provided: 1 sushi making class & 3 dinners (all other food and drink throughout the tour is not included)
Activities as below

Accommodation style:

For comfort and convenience, all of our family tours stay in carefully chosen hotels. After a day full of adventures, you’ll have a comfortable room to relax in together, with options to upgrade if you’d like a little extra space. Please request this on booking.

Included activities:

Visit Sensoji Temple at night (Tokyo)
Visit TeamLab Borderless (Tokyo)
Visit Akihabara – Japan’s “Electric Town” (Tokyo)
Visit a Tokyo arcade (Tokyo)
Visit Yanaka Ginza shopping street (Tokyo)
Visit Meiji Shrine (Tokyo)
Visit Harajuku District (Tokyo)
Visit Shibuya Crossing (Tokyo)
Join a sushi masterclass (Tokyo)
Enjoy a teppanyaki group dinner (Tokyo)
Take a cable car to Owakudani (Hakone)
Relax in a traditional onsen (Hakone)
Sail to Miyajima Island (Hiroshima)
Witness the enormous floating torii gate (Hiroshima)
Take the Miyajima Ropeway & pass by the great torii at Itsukushima Shrine (Hiroshima)
Join a charm-making experience at Okeiko (Hiroshima)
Visit the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum & Atomic Bomb Dome (Hiroshima)
Visit Himeji Castle (Kyoto)
Explore the Arashiyama Bamboo Forest & Tenryuji Temple (Kyoto)
Visit Toei Kyoto Studio Park (Kyoto)
Take part in a traditional tea ceremony at Camellia (Kyoto)
Visit Kiyomizu-dera Temple (Kyoto)
Visit Fushimi Inari Shrine (Kyoto)
Walk through Gion (Kyoto)
Enjoy a farewell dinner (Kyoto)

dayInfo.description: Tokyo: Touch down in Tokyo and meet your Adventure Leader, who’ll give you the lowdown on what’s ahead and help everyone get to know each other. We’ll kick things off in true Japanese style with a hands-on sushi masterclass in Asakusa. Learn the art of rolling the perfect sushi from a pro chef — then enjoy the best part, tucking into your creations for dinner! As evening falls, take a stroll through the glowing lanterns of Sensoji Temple, one of Tokyo’s most iconic sights. Seeing it lit up at night is a truly magical way to start your adventure. After that, the evening is yours to explore Tokyo your way — maybe grab a snack from a local street stall or enjoy a sweet treat with the family before calling it a night.

Tokyo: This morning kicks off with the dazzling world of TeamLab Borderless at the MORI Building — an immersive art experience where light, colour and imagination swirl together in every direction. Get ready for a few “wow” moments (and plenty of great family photos!). Next, we’ll head to Akihabara, Tokyo’s famous Electric Town, packed with anime and manga stores, quirky shops and buzzing gaming arcades. After some free time for lunch, it’s game on! Test your skills in a round of arcade fun — from retro classics to modern favourites — as your Adventure Leader runs a friendly group challenge to bring out everyone’s competitive side. Later, we’ll slow the pace with a visit to Yanaka Ginza, a charming old-town shopping street lined with family-run stalls and snack shops. It’s the perfect spot to grab a local treat and catch a glimpse of Tokyo’s everyday life. In the evening, enjoy some free time. You might want to visit the Dawn Avatar Robot Café, where robot servers are remotely operated by people living with disabilities. It’s a truly inspiring and heartwarming experience that blends innovation, inclusivity and fun — perfect for the whole family.

Tokyo: Start the day with a visit to Meiji Shrine, dedicated to the emperor who helped shape modern Japan. Nestled in a peaceful forest, it’s a calm and beautiful spot to learn about Japanese culture and traditions. Next, step into the colourful world of Harajuku, Tokyo’s ultimate fashion district. Wander the vibrant streets, browse quirky second-hand stores like Chicago, or stop for a bite at one of the many family-friendly cafés and restaurants. There’s plenty to see, taste, and explore for visitors of all ages. In the afternoon, experience the organized chaos of Shibuya Crossing, the busiest pedestrian intersection in the world. While you’re there, don’t miss the Hachiko Statue, a symbol of loyalty and one of Tokyo’s most beloved meeting spots — perfect for a quick family photo.

Tokyo: Today is all yours to explore at your own pace. Spend the morning and afternoon discovering Tokyo however you like, then we’ll regroup later for a delicious group dinner. Your Adventure Leader will have plenty of suggestions to make the most of your day, including: Hanayashiki Amusement Park – Japan’s oldest theme park, perfect for families. Hoppy Street – a lively area filled with local eateries. Kappabashi Kitchen Street – famous for cooking goods and fun souvenirs. Kawaguchiko Tour – enjoy breathtaking views of Mount Fuji. Tokyo Tower – one of the city’s most recognisable landmarks. Tokyo Skytree – the tallest tower in Japan, with sweeping city views. Amita Sumo Dojo Experience – get a taste of traditional Japanese sport. Today is also the day to forward your big luggage from Tokyo to Hiroshima, so make sure to pack a smaller bag for your night in Hakone. In the evening, come together for a sizzling teppanyaki group dinner. It’s the perfect chance for everyone to relax, swap stories, and check in mid-way through the trip — plus, watching your food cooked right in front of you is always a hit with kids!

Hakone: This morning, we say goodbye to the buzz of Tokyo and head into the mountains of Hakone. Hop on the Romance Car to Hakone-Yumoto and enjoy some free time for lunch before the afternoon adventures begin. From Gora Station, take the cable car and ropeway up to Owakudani, a dramatic volcanic valley filled with steaming vents and otherworldly landscapes. Then we’ll continue down to Togendai and set sail across Lake Ashi on a fun pirate ship, taking in the stunning mountain views before arriving at Moto Hakone-ko. A short bus ride then brings us back to Hakone-Yumoto. In the evening, the whole family can unwind in the soothing waters of a traditional Japanese onsen, the perfect way to relax and recharge after a full day of exploring.

Hiroshima: Enjoy a relaxed morning in Hakone before starting the journey west. From Odawara Station, board the famous bullet train and watch the Japanese countryside zip by as we make our way to Hiroshima. On arrival, we’ll take a short ride to your accommodation so everyone can settle in and refresh. This evening, it’s time to try a local family favourite for dinner — okonomiyaki, a savoury pancake packed with flavour and cooked right in front of you. Hiroshima claims it makes the best version of this dish (though Osaka might disagree!), but either way, it’s always a hit with kids and adults alike.

Miyajima & Hiroshima: Kick off the day with a trip to Miyajima Island, one of Japan’s most iconic spots. Wander through Itsukushima Shrine, perched above the water on wooden stilts, and marvel at the huge floating torii gate rising from the sea. If the tide’s low, you can even walk right up to it across the sand — a magical moment for the whole family. Next, get hands-on with tradition at Okeiko Japan, where you’ll join a charm-making class and craft your own keepsake to take home. In the afternoon, we’ll return to Hiroshima to visit the Peace Memorial Park. This moving space is a chance to learn about the events of 1945 and see how the city has rebuilt and transformed itself, offering a powerful lesson in resilience and hope.

Kyoto: Today, we journey to Kyoto, but first we’ll stop at Himeji Castle, Japan’s most iconic and best-preserved feudal fortress. This UNESCO World Heritage Site and National Treasure is famous for its original wooden structure, clever defensive design, and dazzling white exterior — earning it the nickname “White Heron Castle.” It’s a perfect place for the whole family to explore and snap some memorable photos. From Himeji, we’ll continue on to Kyoto. After checking into the hotel, enjoy some time to rest and refresh. In the evening, families can opt in for a karaoke session, a fun and lively way to try a beloved Japanese pastime together — perfect for singing, laughing, and making memories.

Kyoto: This morning, we’ll head to Arashiyama, one of Kyoto’s most scenic districts. Wander through the enchanting Bamboo Forest, where towering stalks sway gently overhead, and soak up the serene atmosphere. Then visit the historic Tenryuji Temple, a UNESCO World Heritage site surrounded by beautifully maintained gardens — a peaceful spot for the whole family to explore. In the afternoon, step back in time at the Toei Kyoto Studio Park, a unique blend of theme park and working film set. Stroll through streets that recreate an Edo-period town, watch live filming demonstrations, and discover how historical dramas are brought to life. It’s a fun, interactive way for families to dive into Japan’s movie and cultural history.

Kyoto: Begin the day with a traditional tea ceremony at Camellia, where you’ll watch the graceful rituals of pouring and preparing matcha tea before trying your hand at whisking your own bowl. Sweet treats are served alongside, making this a calm and delicious experience for the whole family. For a truly authentic touch, you can also rent a kimono and take part in the ceremony dressed in traditional attire. Next, visit Kiyomizu-dera Temple, one of Japan’s most iconic Buddhist landmarks and a UNESCO World Heritage site. Then, head to the striking Fushimi Inari Shrine, famous for its thousands of red torii gates that wind up the mountainside. Families can choose to hike to the top for breathtaking views of Kyoto or stay at the base to enjoy local street food and shopping until the group reunites. In the evening, join your Adventure Leader for a short orientation walk through Gion, Kyoto’s historic district filled with wooden teahouses and lantern-lit streets. Afterward, the night is yours to enjoy dinner and explore Kyoto at your own pace.

Nara or Osaka: Today is all about choosing your own adventure! Spend the day exploring Kyoto, Nara, or Osaka at your own pace before we gather in the evening for a special goodbye dinner with the group. Here are some family-friendly ideas to make the most of your day: Kyoto Railway Museum – interactive exhibits and real trains for enthusiasts of all ages. Bicycle rental – cycle through Kyoto’s quiet backstreets and riverside paths. Golden Pavilion (Kinkaku-ji) – one of Japan’s most photographed temples, shimmering in gold leaf. Nara Park – meet the friendly deer that roam freely through the grounds. Osaka Aquarium – one of the world’s largest, home to whale sharks and penguins. Universal Studios Japan – a family favourite with rides and themed attractions. In the evening, reunite with your Adventure Leader and travel crew for a farewell dinner, the perfect way to celebrate the end of your unforgettable Japan family adventure.

Kyoto: Your Japan family adventure comes to an end today. Whether you are heading off to your next destination or making your way back home, we hope you leave with unforgettable memories from the amazing adventures you have shared. If you would like to extend your stay, we can help arrange additional nights for an extra fee – just let us know in advance.

tourName: Japan family holiday, private departure
